novel_text:
The rain came down in sheets, not cleansing, never cleansing in this city, but simply moving the grime around. From his third-floor window, Peter watched the water turn the back court into a slick, grey mirror reflecting a sky the colour of a day-old bruise. The world was a tenement square, bounded by soot-stained sandstone and the private lives stacked one on top of the other, all breathing the same coal-thick air. And across that square, directly opposite, was Ewan’s window. A mirror to his own.

Most days, it was just a dark rectangle. But sometimes, especially in the gloaming when the lights began to flicker on, he’d see a silhouette. A shape moving, broad-shouldered and quick. Ewan. The name was a secret currency Peter traded only with himself, a smooth, worn coin in the pocket of his mind. He’d been there six months, renting the room from old Mrs Gable, and in that time, he’d rewired the whole of Peter’s small world. It wasn’t a thing Ewan had done, not actively. It was in the way he’d take the stairs two at a time, the sound of his boots on the stone a kind of brutalist music. It was in the rare, lopsided smile he’d throw over his shoulder if he caught Peter watching from the landing. It was in the smell of woodsmoke and something sharp, like pine, that clung to his jacket, a scent of forests and open spaces that had no place here in the Gallowgate.

Peter worked at the shipyards, a place of noise and fire, of men shouting over the shriek of metal being rent and tortured into shape. He came home each night with a ringing in his ears and a fine dust of steel in his hair, in his throat. He’d wash at the sink in the kitchen, the cold water failing to scrub the feeling of it all away. Then he would sit with a book, borrowed and dog-eared, and try to find a silence the yard hadn’t stolen. But the real quiet, the only quiet that mattered, came from watching the window opposite. It was a meditation. A prayer to a god he wasn't sure he believed in, for a thing he was sure he was not allowed to want.

One Tuesday, the sky weeping a miserable, persistent drizzle, the meeting happened. Not at the window, but in the close, the cavernous, echoing stairwell that smelled of damp and boiled cabbage. Peter was heading out for messages, his coat collar turned up against the chill, when the main door swung open and Ewan stumbled in, laughing. He wasn't alone. A girl, her hair the colour of cheap butter, was clinging to his arm, her own laughter a high, sharp sound that scraped against the stone walls. Peter froze on the landing, halfway down.

Ewan saw him. His laughter didn't stop, but it changed. It became something performed. "Alright, Peter?" he called up, his voice booming in the enclosed space. The girl giggled and hid her face in Ewan's shoulder.

"Aye," Peter managed, his own voice a dry whisper. He felt like an intruder, a ghost at their feast. He forced his feet to move, to carry him down the last few steps, past them. The scent of Ewan was stronger here, mixed with the girl's cloying perfume. It made his stomach clench. He didn't look at them as he passed, just stared at the tiled floor, at the intricate, grimy pattern of fleurs-de-lis worn smooth by a century of feet. He pushed the heavy door and escaped into the rain, the cold a welcome shock against his hot face. He didn't know why it felt like a betrayal. Ewan was a stranger. Less than a stranger. He was a shape in a window. A sound on the stairs. But the feeling was there all the same, a cold stone in his gut.

He walked without purpose, past the pub where the men were already escaping the day, past the butcher’s with its grim, pale carcasses, past the baker’s whose warmth couldn’t reach him. He thought he could walk it off, this feeling. But it clung to him, as persistent as the Glasgow damp. When he finally returned, the close was empty. The ghost of perfume and laughter was gone. There was only the familiar scent of boiled vegetables and, fainter now, the lingering hint of pine. He climbed the stairs slowly, his boots heavy. As he reached his own door, he saw it. Leaning against the jamb, a single, hand-rolled cigarette. It was Ewan's. He always had one tucked behind his ear. Peter looked around. The landings above and below were empty. The silence was absolute. He picked it up. It was still a little damp from the air, but the tobacco was dry. A peace offering? An apology? Or just a dropped cigarette? He didn’t know. But he slipped it into his pocket, and it felt like a key.

Later, when the city was dark and the only sounds were a distant siren and the lonely clatter of a late-night tram, he stood at his window. He smoked the cigarette, letting the unfamiliar taste of the cheap, strong tobacco coat his tongue. He didn't cough. He smoked it like he'd been doing it his whole life. And as he watched the smoke curl and vanish into the blackness, a light flickered on in the window opposite. Ewan’s silhouette appeared. He stood there for a moment, looking out. Looking, Peter was certain, right at him. Peter’s heart hammered against his ribs, a frantic bird in a cage. He didn't move, didn't breathe. He just stood there, a boy in a window, with a stolen cigarette and a secret hope that was as dangerous and beautiful as a shard of broken glass. And across the chasm of the back court, Ewan raised a hand in a slow, deliberate wave.

The wave changed everything. It was a thread thrown across the void, and Peter grasped it with all the strength of his lonely soul. The next day, he didn't just listen for Ewan’s boots on the stairs; he waited for them. He timed his own departure for the yard to coincide, manufacturing an accident. It was clumsy. He almost fell over him on the first-floor landing.

"Whoa there, lad. In a hurry to get to the fire and brimstone?" Ewan's voice was amused, a low rumble that vibrated through the floor. He steadied Peter with a hand on his arm. His grip was firm, warm through the thin fabric of Peter’s shirt. The contact was a jolt, a brand.

"Sorry. Daydreaming," Peter mumbled, his face burning. He could smell the pine scent again, clean and sharp.

"Aye, you do a lot of that," Ewan said, but there was no mockery in it. His eyes, the colour of peat smoke, held Peter’s for a second too long. "Walk with me a bit." It wasn't a question. They walked out of the tenement and into the pale morning light, falling into step beside each other. The street was already teeming with men heading for the yards and the factories, a river of grey caps and weary shoulders. But for Peter, it was a bubble of silence with Ewan at its centre.

"Saw you last night," Ewan said, not looking at him, his gaze fixed ahead. "At your window."

"I was just…"

"It’s alright." Ewan gave that lopsided smile, a flash of white in his tanned face. "Good to know someone’s keeping watch." He said it like a joke, but his tone was serious. They didn't talk much more, just walked. But it was a conversation all the same. The rhythm of their steps, the way Ewan angled himself slightly, as if to shield Peter from the jostling crowd, the shared glances at a headline on a news-seller's board about troops and borders. When they reached the corner where their paths diverged, Ewan to the delivery depot and Peter to the inferno of the shipyards, Ewan stopped.

"Tonight," he said, his voice low, for Peter’s ears only. "The roof. After it’s dark."

Peter just nodded, his throat too tight for words. The rest of the day was a dream. The roar of the yard was a distant hum, the molten rivets arcing through the air were slow, lazy fireflies. He moved like an automaton, his body performing the tasks his mind had long since abandoned. His mind was on the roof. The roof was a place of myth, accessed by a rusty ladder in the top-floor washhouse. It was a windswept desert of slate and lead, dotted with chimney pots that exhaled the building’s smoky breath. It was a place to be alone, above everything. To be there with Ewan felt like a transgression of a different order entirely.

When night fell, he waited until the sounds of the tenement settled, until the shouts and the wireless radios faded into a low murmur. He crept up the stairs, his heart a frantic drum against his ribs. The ladder was cold and slick with damp. He climbed, emerging into the vast, cold darkness of the Glasgow night. The city was spread out below, a carpet of scattered, smudgy lights under a starless, cloud-heavy sky. And Ewan was there, a dark shape against the lesser dark, sitting on the coping stones, his legs dangling over the edge.

"Thought you might not come," Ewan said, his voice quiet, almost carried away by the wind that swept across the slates.

"You said to," Peter replied, the words simple, but they held the weight of a vow. He walked over and sat beside Ewan, careful not to look down at the sheer drop to the back court.

"Look at it," Ewan gestured out at the city. "Like a spilled jar of embers. All that life down there. All those people in their little boxes. And they haven't a clue we're up here." He turned to look at Peter, and in the faint, reflected glow from the city, his eyes were deep and serious. "Do you ever want to just… fly away from it, Peter?"

"There's nowhere to fly to," Peter said, his voice barely a whisper.

"There's always somewhere." Ewan’s gaze was intense. He reached out, not quickly, but with a slow deliberation that gave Peter a universe of time to pull away. He didn't. Ewan's fingers brushed a stray lock of hair from Peter’s forehead. The touch was feather-light, yet it anchored him to the spot. "I don’t want to fly away from all of it," Ewan said, his voice dropping even lower, a rough, intimate sound. "Not all of it." And then he leaned in, and the world dissolved into the press of his lips against Peter's. It was not like the kiss he had imagined. It was better. It was softer, more questioning. It tasted of tobacco and the cold night air, and it was the first true thing that had ever happened to him. When they broke apart, the city lights below seemed to blur and swim, and Peter knew, with a terrifying certainty, that he was lost. Or found. He wasn't sure which. He only knew he was Ewan's.The silence that followed was more profound than any quiet Peter had ever known. It was not an absence of sound—the city still hummed its ceaseless, mechanical lullaby, the wind still whispered over the slates—but an absence of noise in his own head. The ringing from the shipyard was gone. The anxious static of his own thoughts was gone. There was only the solid warmth of Ewan beside him, the lingering taste of him, and the dizzying panorama of the lights below that no longer looked like a spilled jar of embers, but like a promise. He felt Ewan’s thumb trace a slow line along his jaw, a simple, grounding gesture that said more than words ever could. It said, *I am here. This is real.*

"See?" Ewan’s voice was a low murmur, close to his ear. "Not so hard to fly, is it?" He pulled back a little, though his hand remained, cupping Peter's cheek. His peat-smoke eyes searched Peter’s face in the gloom, looking for something—reassurance, maybe, or a reflection of his own recklessness. "I’ve been watching you, too, Peter. From my window. Wondering what you were reading. Wondering what you were thinking, looking out at all this." He let out a short, soft laugh, a sound utterly different from the booming performance in the close. "Figured I was going mad. Seeing a story in a window that wasn't there."

"The story was there," Peter heard himself say, his voice steadier than he expected. It felt momentous to admit it, to give voice to the silent longing that had structured his days. He dared to look away from Ewan’s eyes and back towards their two windows, twin black squares in the sandstone cliffs of the tenement. They were no longer a mirror and a mystery, but two ends of a secret, a shared geography that only they understood. "I saw you with the girl," he added, the words slipping out before he could stop them, tasting of ash. It wasn't an accusation, just a statement of fact, a piece of the puzzle that didn't fit.

Ewan didn’t flinch. He let his hand drop from Peter’s face and picked up a loose piece of slate, turning it over and over in his fingers. "Mary? She’s… a friend. Sometimes it’s easier to be seen with a friend like that. Keeps the questions away." He glanced at Peter, his expression unreadable. "This world, our world," he gestured vaguely at the tenement, at the city, "it only lets you live in certain ways. You know that. Sometimes you have to build a wall so you can have a garden behind it." He tossed the piece of slate, and they watched it skitter down the roof and disappear into the darkness. "This," he said, turning back to Peter, his meaning clear in the space between them, "is the garden."

They stayed up there for what felt like hours, though it may have been only one. The cold began to seep into their bones, a damp, insistent chill that the warmth between them couldn't entirely banish. Ewan talked. He spoke of a life before Glasgow, of forestry work in the Highlands, of vast, silent hills and the smell of sawdust, of a sky so full of stars it could break your heart. He spoke of leaving, not because he wanted to, but because a small town has more eyes than a city, and less room to hide. Peter, in turn, spoke of his books, of the worlds he escaped into, of the quiet hunger for something more than the grime and the noise. They were just words, but they were building a bridge, plank by plank, across the chasm of the back court, a bridge that felt more real than the stone and steel of the city around them.

The descent was a reversal of the magic. Back down the slick ladder, into the familiar, stale air of the washhouse, the spell of the rooftop began to fray. Every creak of the floorboards, every distant cough from another flat, was a reminder of the world they had to return to. At the landing between their floors, they paused in the thick darkness. There were no words left. Ewan reached out and squeezed Peter’s shoulder, a quick, firm pressure that was both a promise and a warning. Then he was gone, his boots making a soft, retreating sound on the stone steps leading up to his floor. Peter stood alone in the dark, his shoulder tingling where Ewan had touched him, the silence of the close pressing in on him once more.

Back in his room, he didn't turn on the light. He went straight to the window, his old habit, his old ritual. But everything was changed. The back court was no longer a chasm of loneliness. Ewan’s window was no longer a dark rectangle of unknowing. It was an anchor. As he watched, a match flared in the darkness opposite, briefly illuminating Ewan’s face as he lit a cigarette. He didn't wave this time. He didn't have to. He just stood there, a point of light in the gloom, and Peter stood with him, two sentinels guarding a fragile, new-born secret. The city was still grimy, the air still thick, but for the first time since he’d arrived, Peter felt like he was breathing. He was no longer just a boy in a window; he was one half of a story, and he knew, with a certainty that was both thrilling and terrifying, that the first chapter had just come to a close.The following morning, the grey light that filtered through his window felt less like an accusation and more like a soft blanket. The tenement square was still a slick mirror of damp stone, but Peter saw it differently now. He saw it not as a chasm, but as the space that defined the distance between two specific points: his window and Ewan’s. The memory of the rooftop was a low, steady hum beneath the surface of his thoughts. He could still feel the phantom press of Ewan’s lips, the rough texture of his jacket, the astonishing, terrifying safety of his hand on his cheek. When he washed his face, the cold water didn’t feel like a punishment; it was a shock that made the memories sharper, more real. The day ahead, with its noise and its fire, didn’t loom with the same dread. It was simply the price of admission for the night to come.

He didn't have to manufacture an encounter this time. As he pulled on his boots, he heard the familiar, heavy tread on the stairs above. It was a signal. He opened his door and stepped onto the landing just as Ewan was descending. Their eyes met, and the charged silence from the rooftop was there between them again, an invisible, crackling field. Ewan’s lopsided smile was there, too, but it was different now. It was for Peter alone, a private acknowledgment of all that had passed between them in the dark. He didn’t stop, but as he passed, his knuckles brushed against Peter’s, a deliberate, fleeting contact that sent a bolt of heat straight up his arm. "Morning, lad," he said, his voice the same low rumble, but the words were a caress. Peter just nodded, unable to speak, and watched him take the stairs two at a time, the brutalist music now a symphony. He followed a few moments later, walking through the ghost of Ewan’s pine scent as if it were a benediction.

At the shipyard, the cacophony was the same, the air just as thick with the metallic tang of tortured steel. But Peter felt insulated from it, encased in a bubble of memory and anticipation. He worked with a fierce, focused energy he hadn't possessed before, his movements sure and rhythmic. The other men, with their rough jokes and their casual complaints about wives and the price of beer, seemed to be speaking a foreign language. He was one of them, wearing the same grime-stiffened overalls, his hands calloused from the same labour, but he was no longer of them. He had a secret garden, and the shrieking, fiery hell of the yard was the wall that surrounded it. He found himself smiling once, a small, involuntary quirk of his lips, as he guided a white-hot rivet into place, and caught one of the older men, Davie, watching him with a curious expression. Peter quickly looked away, his heart thumping. The garden was a beautiful thing, but its walls were thin.

They fell into a silent routine, a language without words. A book left on the top step of Peter’s flight meant the roof, if the weather held. A single chalk mark on the brick by the main door, low down where only someone looking for it would see, meant to wait by the window after dark. Sometimes, Ewan would leave him things. A perfectly ripe apple on his windowsill, discovered in the morning. A small, intricately carved wooden bird, left tucked into the hinge of his door, smelling faintly of the forest. These were not peace offerings or apologies; they were sentences in a conversation, tangible proof that Peter was not imagining it, that the man with peat-smoke eyes was thinking of him even when they were apart. Peter, in return, would leave a passage marked in a book, a poem about stars or the sea, a story of a distant, kinder land. He’d leave it where he knew Ewan would find it, a quiet offering from his world to Ewan’s.

One evening, as Peter was climbing the stairs, he ran into Mrs Gable coming down from the top-floor washhouse, a wicker basket of damp laundry propped on her hip. She was a woman made of faded floral prints and the smell of carbolic soap, her eyes small and sharp behind her spectacles. "Ah, Peter," she said, her voice a reedy counterpoint to the close's usual echoes. "You're looking… brighter, these days. Got a spring in your step." She smiled, a small, knowing crinkle around her eyes. "It's that friend you've made, I expect. The big lad from upstairs, Mr Scott. It’s good to have a pal in a place like this." Peter’s blood ran cold. He felt the heat rise in his face, a traitorous blush. "He's a nice boy," she continued, oblivious. "Always has a kind word. Though I do wish he'd wipe his boots. He tracks the whole of the Highlands in with him." She chuckled and continued her slow descent. Peter stood frozen, his hand gripping the bannister. *A pal. A friend.* The words were so simple, so normal. So utterly wrong. It was a reminder of the wall, of the performance. And a warning that even the most innocent eyes were watching.The chill from the iron bannister seeped into his palm, a cold that spread up his arm and settled in his chest, far deeper than the Glasgow damp. *A pal*. The word was a perfectly cut key for a lock that didn't exist, a convenient label for something wild and unnameable. Mrs Gable, in her floral, soap-scented innocence, had held up a mirror, and in it Peter saw not himself and Ewan, but how the world saw them. Two lads, two friends. A safe, understandable equation. He understood, with a sickening lurch, that Ewan’s performance with Mary in the close hadn't just been for him; it was for the entire building. It was part of the wall around the garden, and Peter had been too lost in the beauty of the flowers to even notice the bricks. Back in his room, the window felt different. It was no longer a private vantage point, but a stage. He felt a hundred pairs of eyes on his back, the collective, unseen gaze of the tenement.

The chalk mark appeared two days later. A faint white dash on the grimy brick, a whisper in their silent language. It meant the roof. A week ago, his heart would have soared. Now, it beat a frantic, trapped rhythm against his ribs, a frantic bird that had suddenly realised the dimensions of its cage. Every step he took up the final flights of stairs that evening felt reckless. He imagined doors opening, heads peering out, a voice calling, "Where are you off to, lad, at this hour?" The air in the close, thick with the ghosts of a hundred dinners and a thousand conversations, seemed to press in on him, heavy with judgment. When he pushed open the heavy door to the washhouse, the familiar smell of damp linen and cold stone did nothing to calm him. He was a trespasser, and the magic of the ascent had been replaced by the grim anxiety of being caught.

Ewan was already there, a silhouette against a sky that had been washed clean by an earlier rain, leaving behind a deep, bruised purple pricked with a few, determined stars. He was smoking, the red tip of his cigarette a tiny, defiant ember in the gloom. He didn't speak as Peter approached, just watched him, his gaze steady. Peter sat beside him on the coping stones, the drop to the back court below seeming more perilous than ever before. He couldn't shake the feeling that they were utterly exposed, two figures picked out against the skyline for all of Glasgow to see.
"You're jumpy tonight," Ewan said, his voice a low rumble that barely disturbed the quiet. He flicked the butt of his cigarette into the darkness, a falling star that extinguished itself. "Like a hare that's heard the dogs."

"Mrs Gable spoke to me," Peter said, the words coming out in a rush. "She called you my friend. My pal." He hated how small his voice sounded, how fraught with panic. Ewan was quiet for a long moment, his gaze on the sprawling lights of the city. When he finally turned to Peter, his expression wasn't mocking, or dismissive. It was weary, and older than Peter had ever seen it. "Aye," he said softly. "And that's what we'll be, to her. To all of them. It's the only story they'll buy, so it's the only one we can sell." He reached out and tucked a piece of Peter's hair behind his ear, a gesture so gentle it almost broke him. "Doesn't change the story we tell each other, up here."

Suddenly, from below, came the sharp, metallic clang of the washhouse door slamming shut, followed by the sound of a woman's voice, raised in complaint, the words indistinct but the tone sharp as vinegar. They both froze. In an instant, Ewan’s hand was on Peter’s arm, pulling him back from the edge, down into the deeper shadows of a chimney stack. They crouched there, side by side in the dark, barely breathing. The sounds from below faded, replaced once more by the wind and the distant city hum. The danger had passed. But in the close, shared darkness, Peter could feel the hammering of Ewan's heart, or perhaps it was his own; he couldn't tell where one began and the other ended. The thrill was gone, replaced by the cold, hard reality of fear.

When the silence had stretched out long enough to feel safe again, Ewan let out a slow breath. He didn't move away. Instead, he turned in the narrow space, his knee brushing Peter's, his face so close Peter could see the faint starlight reflected in his eyes. The fear had stripped away the performance, the easy confidence, leaving something more raw and essential. "This is the price, Peter," he whispered, his voice rough with an emotion Peter couldn't name. "This is it. Hiding in the shadows. Always listening for footsteps on the stairs." He leaned in, and this time there was no questioning softness in the kiss. It was desperate and deep, a frantic affirmation in the face of all the things that would deny them. It tasted of fear and cheap tobacco and a fierce, defiant tenderness. It wasn't about flying; it was about holding on, a grim anchor in a storm.

The journey down was silent, a retreat from a battlefield. They parted on the landing with a shared look that was heavier than any embrace, an acknowledgment of the new weight they both carried. Back in his room, Peter stood at the window, but he wasn't looking at Ewan's dark square opposite. He was looking at all the other windows, the dozens of dim, curtained squares stacked one on top of the other. They were no longer just the backdrop to his private world; they were watchtowers. He saw Mrs Gable’s window, and the flat of the man who shouted at his wireless, and the home of the young couple whose baby cried through the night. He saw a city full of walls and rules, and he and Ewan were on the wrong side of all of them. The hope that had bloomed so brightly on the rooftop now had thorns, and he knew, with a certainty that was as cold and hard as the shipyard steel, that their secret garden was a beautiful, impossible, and desperately dangerous place to live.The fear, he discovered, did not recede with the morning light. It was a new colour added to his world, a sickly yellow-grey that stained the dawn and tainted the familiar taste of his tea. Peter woke with the echo of the washhouse door in his bones, his sleep having been a shallow, restless affair punctuated by dreams of falling. When he looked out his window, he no longer saw just the slick, rain-washed stone of the back court. He saw sightlines. He saw angles of observation. He noted the way Mrs Gable’s net curtains never hung quite straight, leaving a gap just wide enough for an eye, and how the window of the flat below Ewan’s, a family with three noisy children, was almost always propped open an inch, like a listening ear. The tenement was no longer a stack of private lives; it was a panopticon of grimy sandstone, and he felt pinned by its unseen, collective gaze.

Their silent language faltered. There were no more chalk marks by the door, no more carved birds or surprise apples on his sill. The steps on the landing where he might have left a book with a marked page felt too exposed, the act itself imbued with a new and terrible significance. The meetings on the stairs ceased to be manufactured accidents and became instead exercises in avoidance. If he heard Ewan's boots, he would wait behind his door, his hand on the knob, until the sound had faded completely. He told himself it was caution, the lesson learned in the cold shadows of the chimney stack. But a darker, colder thought whispered that perhaps the garden had been abandoned, its single, fragile bloom left to wither on the vine. The silence from Ewan’s side of the court was absolute, and Peter’s loneliness, which had been briefly banished, returned with a vengeance, sharper and more painful for its absence.

The change in him did not go unnoticed at the yard. Where before he had been quiet but competent, he was now jumpy and distracted, his hands fumbling, his mind miles away. The roar of the furnaces, the shriek of the metal, no longer formed a dull, insulating wall but a cacophony that frayed his already raw nerves. The casual, crude banter of the other men, once just background noise, now felt like a constant interrogation. Every joke about a lass, every boast of a weekend conquest, seemed directed at him, a test he was failing. One afternoon, during a lull, Davie, the old riveter with eyes that had seen too many winters, sidled up to him. "Everything alright with you, son?" he asked, his voice surprisingly gentle amid the din. "You're a million miles away. Got troubles at home?" Peter flinched as if struck. The simple, kindly meant question felt like a spotlight. "No. Just tired," he mumbled, turning his attention fiercely to a coil of rope, his face burning. The lie felt flimsy, pathetic. He could feel Davie's gaze on him for a long moment before the old man sighed and moved away. Peter knew then that the walls of the garden were not just outside; they had to be built inside himself, and his were proving to be made of glass.

After nearly a week of this suffocating silence, a week in which Peter felt himself shrinking, turning back into the ghost he was before Ewan, he broke. He could not bear the not-knowing. The fear of being caught was terrible, but the fear of being abandoned was worse. That evening, he listened for the tell-tale sound of Ewan’s return, his heart a frantic drum. He heard the main door groan open and slam shut, followed by the heavy, familiar tread on the stone. He didn’t hesitate. He pulled open his own door and stepped out onto the landing, blocking the way. Ewan was halfway up the flight of stairs, his head down, and he almost walked into Peter before he stopped, looking up in surprise. His face was shadowed in the gloom, his expression unreadable. For a terrible second, Peter thought he saw a stranger.

"You've been avoiding me," Peter said. The words came out sounding more like an accusation than he intended, his voice tight and low. Ewan didn't answer immediately. He looked past Peter, up the stairs and then down, his eyes scanning the shadowed landings, a soldier checking for snipers. Only when he seemed satisfied that they were alone did he meet Peter’s gaze. The weariness Peter had seen on the roof was there again, etched into the lines around his eyes. "I've been careful," he corrected, his voice a near whisper. "There's a difference." He took the last few steps until he was standing on the same landing, so close Peter could smell the damp wool of his jacket and the cold night air clinging to him. The scent of pine was faint, almost lost. "You think I want this quiet? This hiding?" Ewan’s voice was rough, laced with a frustration that mirrored Peter's own. "I saw Davie talking to you at the yard gate yesterday. I saw Mrs Gable watch you all the way down the street this morning from her window. They're not looking for anything, Peter. Not yet. But they're looking. And that's how it starts." He reached out, not to touch, but his hand hovered in the space between them, a gesture of aborted comfort. "This isn't a story in one of your books, lad. The world doesn't just let you be. You have to be cleverer than it is. You have to be quieter. It means… going without. So we don't lose everything." He finally let his hand drop. The space between them felt vast and cold, a chasm of brutal reality. Peter understood then. This wasn't a retreat; it was a strategy. It wasn't the end of their story, but the grim, unwritten rules of its telling.Ewan's words were a cold, hard key turning in a lock Peter hadn't known was rusted shut. He went back into his room and closed the door, the soft click of the latch sounding like a cell door sliding home. *It means going without.* The phrase echoed in the sudden, profound quiet of his small room. It wasn't the romantic, pining silence of before, filled with daydreams and unspoken hopes. This was a tactical silence, a necessary barrenness. The garden wasn't abandoned; it had been plunged into a perpetual winter to protect its roots. Peter went to the window, his familiar post, but he felt no comfort there. He understood now that his vigil had been naive, a blissful ignorance. He had been admiring the view from the battlefield, mistaking the glint of enemy spyglasses for friendly stars. He looked at Ewan’s window, a dark, inscrutable rectangle, and for the first time, he felt the true weight of the chasm between them. It wasn’t just a distance of stone and air, but of risk and consequence.

The days that followed were an education in this new quiet. It was a language of absences. The absence of a timed departure in the morning, the absence of a lingering scent of pine in the stairwell, the absence of a hand-rolled cigarette or a piece of carved wood. They became two ghosts haunting the same tenement, their paths weaving around each other with a precision that was heartbreaking in its skill. Peter would hear Ewan’s boots on the stone and press his back against his door, holding his breath until the sound passed. He learned to read the building's rhythms, to know when the landings would be empty, when Mrs Gable was occupied with her washing, when the men from the lower floors had all departed for the pubs. He moved through the close with a furtive grace he hadn't known he possessed, his world shrinking to the path between his door, the stairs, and the street. Life became a series of subtractions, and he felt himself being pared down to his essential, fearful self.

The shipyard was no longer a hell he escaped from, but a place of strange respite. Amid the deafening, all-consuming noise, he could not hear the silence that screamed at him back in the tenement. The fire and the fury of the work demanded his full attention, and for eight hours a day, he could almost forget the constant, low-level hum of anxiety. He became a better worker. His movements were swift and certain because his mind had no room for daydreams. He was present, anchored in the brutal reality of the forge, and the men, sensing this shift, began to treat him with a different kind of respect. He was no longer the quiet, bookish lad, but one of them, a man who pulled his weight and kept his head down. Davie clapped him on the shoulder one afternoon, a gesture of rough approval. "That's it, son," he'd grunted over the noise. "Whatever was eating at you, you've sweated it out." Peter didn't have the heart to tell him that he hadn't sweated it out; he'd just learned to hide it better.

Their only point of contact was the windows, and even that changed. There were no more waves, no more silhouettes lingering for long moments. It became a silent, nightly check-in, as austere and necessary as a soldier's watch. Just after the last of the tenement's lights were extinguished, Peter would stand in the darkness of his room and wait. And across the court, a match would flare. One single, brief ignition. Ewan would light a cigarette, the tiny flame illuminating his face for no more than a second, just long enough for Peter to see that he was there, that he was watching. Ewan wouldn't stay at the window; he would retreat into the darkness of his own room. But the glowing red ember of his cigarette would move back and forth in the blackness, a tiny, restless planet in their shared, secret solar system. Peter would watch until the ember was finally extinguished, and only then would he feel a measure of peace, enough to allow sleep to claim him. It was a conversation stripped to its barest element: *I am here. You are there. We are still here.* It was everything, and it was almost nothing at all.

One Tuesday, a month into this silent siege, the routine was broken. Peter was returning late from an errand, a new book tucked under his arm, the sky already the colour of lead. As he pushed open the heavy main door, he saw a cluster of people on the first-floor landing. It was the family from below Ewan’s flat, the mother holding a crying baby, the father looking grim, and beside them, a stout man in a dark suit. A doctor. Peter’s first instinct was to retreat, to make himself invisible, but he was already in the close, his presence noted by the father's weary glance. He began to climb the stairs, his head down, murmuring a quiet "Evening." As he drew level with them, the doctor was speaking in low, serious tones. "...keep him warm, plenty of fluids. This fever is a nasty one. It's going through the whole Gallowgate like a bad rumour." Peter’s heart seized. He chanced a look up the stairs, towards Ewan’s floor, a frantic, unspoken question in his eyes. The doctor, packing his bag, caught the look. "Don't you worry, lad," he said, mistaking the direction of Peter’s concern. "Your friend upstairs is tough as an old boot. I was just up there. Same thing, a bad chill and a devil of a cough. But he'll be right as rain in a few days." The doctor snapped his bag shut. "Seems to be sharing it with half the building." The words hit Peter with the force of a physical blow. Ewan was sick. Alone in his room. And Peter was trapped on the other side of a few feet of stone and a wall of suffocating caution. The fear he had been living with for weeks was suddenly dwarfed by a new, more terrifying one. The fear of loss, real and absolute. The rules of their quiet game suddenly seemed like the most foolish, pointless thing in the world.The doctor and the family dispersed, their footsteps and hushed worries fading into the tenement’s low hum, leaving Peter alone on the landing. The air, moments before just stale and damp, now felt thin, unbreathable. All the caution he had so painstakingly cultivated, all the lessons in silence and avoidance, evaporated like steam in the cold air. The intricate chess game he and Ewan had been playing against the world was swept from the board by a single, brutal fact: Ewan was sick. He was one floor away, burning with a fever, in a room as solitary as Peter’s own. The image of Ewan, the strong, vital man who smelled of forests and took the stairs two at a time, laid low and alone, was an agony that dwarfed every other fear. The risk of a curious glance or a piece of idle gossip seemed a paltry price to pay compared to the cost of inaction, of leaving Ewan to suffer in the name of a strategy that had already failed to bring them anything but a colder, more profound isolation.

He didn't return to his room to hide. He went back with a purpose that felt like a fire in his veins, melting the ice of the past weeks. The small, sparse room was no longer a prison cell but a base of operations. He moved with a decisiveness that surprised himself. From his small larder, he took the last of his tea, a precious quarter-ounce wrapped in paper. He found the lemon he had bought on a whim two days ago, a small extravagance he had been saving, its bright, sharp scent a promise of something clean and restorative. He filled his kettle with fresh water from the sink and grabbed the cleanest cloth he owned from a drawer. These were meagre offerings, the humble provisions of a shipyard worker, but as he gathered them, they felt like weapons. Each item was an act of defiance, a clear, unequivocal statement against the tyranny of their self-imposed silence. He was no longer just a boy in a window, or a ghost on the stairs; he was a friend, a pal, and he was about to prove what that truly meant.

The single flight of stairs leading to Ewan’s floor had never seemed so long. It was a vertical no-man's-land, exposed and treacherous. With the kettle of water in one hand and his small collection of supplies in the other, he began the ascent. Every creak of the ancient wooden treads under his boots was a gunshot in the quiet. He could feel the eyes of the building on him, Mrs Gable’s, the man with the wireless, the family with the crying baby. He imagined their doors opening, their faces appearing, their questions hanging in the air. *You're breaking the rules*, a voice in his head screamed, Ewan’s voice. *This is not clever. This is not quiet.* But he pushed the voice down. Cleverness had left Ewan alone and shivering. Quiet had built a wall between them when what they needed was a bridge. He reached the landing outside Ewan’s door, his heart hammering against his ribs not with fear of being caught, but with the terrifying, beautiful certainty of what he was about to do.

He stood there for a moment, the kettle growing heavy in his hand, the smell of damp stone and boiled cabbage filling his lungs. He listened. From inside the room, he could hear a sound he had never associated with Ewan: a rough, ragged cough that spoke of deep-seated illness. The sound cut through his last vestiges of hesitation. He raised his free hand, the knuckles white, and knocked. The sound was soft, just three quick taps, but in the echoing cavern of the close it sounded like a declaration of war. He waited, holding his breath. For a long moment, there was only the sound of that terrible cough in reply. Then, a shuffling noise, a muttered curse, and the slow, heavy scrape of footsteps. The lock turned with a loud, metallic clunk, and the door opened a few inches, revealing a sliver of darkness. Ewan’s face appeared in the gap, pale and slick with sweat in the gloom, his peat-smoke eyes clouded with fever and confusion. "Peter? What the hell are you doing?" his voice was a raw, broken rasp. He looked not just sick, but angry, his gaze darting past Peter to the empty stairwell behind him.

"The doctor told me," Peter said, his own voice low and steady, a stark contrast to the panic roiling inside him. He held up the lemon and the packet of tea. "He said you had the fever. I brought you something." He didn't wait for permission. He pushed gently against the door, an undeniable pressure that was both a question and a demand. Ewan, his strength sapped by the illness, offered no resistance. He stumbled back, letting Peter into the room, and closed the door behind him, plunging them into near-total darkness. The room was cold, the air thick and stale with the scent of sickness, though underneath it all, the faint, ghostly trace of pine lingered like a memory. As his eyes adjusted, Peter could make out the spartan details: a narrow iron bed, a single wooden chair, a small table cluttered with tools for woodcarving, and dozens of tiny, intricately carved birds, perched on every available surface. Ewan leaned heavily against the closed door, his body wracked by a shiver. He looked utterly spent, the solid, unshakeable man reduced to a fragile shadow. "You shouldn't be here," Ewan rasped, though the words lacked their usual force. "It's not safe." Peter ignored him. He walked past him to the small table, set down his supplies, and turned to face him, the small, carved birds his silent audience. "No," Peter said, his voice imbued with a quiet authority he didn't know he possessed. "It's not safe for you to be alone."A flicker of anger in Ewan’s fever-bright eyes died out, replaced by a profound weariness, as if the effort of being angry was simply too much to sustain. He watched, swaying slightly, as Peter moved about the small, cold room with a quiet, unnerving competence. Peter’s eyes swept over the space, noting the tiny, grate-fronted fireplace, its black maw empty and cold, a bucket of coal and a handful of kindling beside it. There was no hesitation in his movements. He knelt on the grimy hearthrug, his back to Ewan, and began to arrange the kindling with the focused precision of a man building a bomb, or a prayer. The scratch of the match, the tiny burst of sulphur and flame, was the only sound besides Ewan's shallow, ragged breathing.

Ewan didn't protest further. The fight had gone out of him, leeched away by the fever. He sank onto the edge of his narrow iron bed, the frame groaning under his weight, and watched Peter as if he were a strange apparition. He watched as Peter coaxed the small flame, feeding it scraps of paper and then splinters of wood until it caught, a small, hungry thing that began to throw a dancing, uncertain light onto the walls. The shadows of the carved birds leaped and swayed. Peter filled a small, soot-blackened pot with water from his kettle and set it on the grate to warm, then meticulously sliced the lemon on a clean plate he found on the windowsill. The sharp, clean scent of the citrus cut through the stale air of the sickroom, a bright, defiant note in the fug of illness and coal smoke. It was an act of such simple, domestic care that it felt more intimate, more shockingly profound, than any kiss in the dark.

When the water was steaming, Peter poured it into a tin mug, adding the tea and a thick slice of lemon, the steam rising in a fragrant cloud. He carried it over to the bed. Ewan was shivering now, a deep, uncontrollable tremor that shook his broad frame. His hands, when he reached for the mug, were unsteady. Peter’s own hands closed around Ewan’s, steadying them, feeling the burning, dry heat of his skin. The contact was electric, a jolt of pure information: *fever, weakness, life*. "Drink," Peter said, his voice soft but firm, and he held the mug for Ewan, tilting it to his lips as if he were a child. Ewan drank, his eyes closing, a low groan of relief escaping his throat. After a few sips, he sagged back against the thin pillow. Peter took the cloth he’d brought, dipped it in the remaining cool water from the kettle, wrung it out, and gently laid it across Ewan’s forehead. Ewan flinched at the initial shock of the cold, then relaxed into it with a sigh that seemed to come from the very depths of his soul.

With Ewan finally still, his breathing a little easier, Peter had a moment to truly see the room. It was Ewan’s whole world. The walls were bare but for the birds. They were everywhere. A flock of gulls perched on the high shelf above the bed, their wings half-spread as if ready for flight. A tiny, perfect wren sat on the corner of the table. An owl, its wooden eyes seeming to hold a deep, ancient knowledge, was tucked beside a pile of books. They weren’t just carvings; they were personalities, each one captured in a moment of life. This was the forest Ewan carried inside him, the open space he had spoken of on the roof. It was his escape, his secret language made tangible. Reaching out, Peter gently touched the smooth, polished head of a blackbird resting on the bedpost. He felt the patient hours of work in the wood, the love. He was no longer just standing in Ewan’s room; he had been allowed into the heart of the garden.

"You’re a damn fool, Peter," Ewan’s voice was a rough whisper from the bed, his eyes still closed. The words held no anger now, only a raw, gravelly exhaustion. "A bloody, stubborn fool."

Peter turned from the birds and looked at the man on the bed, at the damp cloth on his forehead, at the vulnerability in the line of his jaw. He thought of the weeks of silence, the fear, the cold expanse of the back court. He thought of the doctor’s casual words on the stairs and the terror that had bloomed in his chest, a terror that had proven stronger than any rule. He walked back to the bedside and sat on the single wooden chair, pulling it close.

"Aye," Peter said quietly, his voice full of a feeling he couldn't name. "Maybe I am." He reached out and adjusted the blanket, pulling it higher over Ewan’s shoulder. "But you were alone."Ewan didn’t answer, but the tension in his shoulders seemed to dissolve, a quiet surrender. He let his head fall back against the pillow, his breath a ragged sigh. The small fire Peter had built spat and crackled in the grate, a living, breathing thing in the cold room. It threw a warm, flickering glow on the bare floorboards and the flock of wooden birds, making their shadows dance like restless spirits. Outside, the city hummed its indifferent tune, but inside this small, fourth-floor room, a new kind of silence settled. It was not the strained, fearful quiet of the past weeks, but a shared stillness, deep and resonant, a space where two people could simply be, without pretence or performance. The world had been shrunk down to the dimensions of this room, to the sound of the fire and the rhythm of a fevered man’s breathing.

Peter stayed in the chair, a sentry at his post. He watched the rise and fall of Ewan’s chest, the slight twitch of his eyelids. The anger and defiance that had propelled him up the stairs had subsided, replaced by a low, steady hum of purpose. He was where he was supposed to be. He got up quietly and added a few more lumps of coal to the fire, coaxing it into a stronger, more consistent heat that began to push back the room’s bone-deep chill. He refilled the mug with warm water, this time lacing it with a squeeze of lemon and a spoonful of the precious sugar he’d thought to grab from his own cupboard. He saw Ewan's carving tools lying on the table, a jumble of well-worn knives and gouges next to a half-finished hawk, its wings poised in an intricate state of arrested motion. He ran a finger over the smooth, sanded wood, feeling the ghost of Ewan’s hands, the same hands that were now too weak to hold a mug steady. The contrast was a sharp, painful ache in his chest.

Hours passed. The tenement outside fell into a deeper quiet as the last of the wireless sets were switched off and the final arguments faded behind closed doors. Peter must have dozed, his head nodding forward, for he startled awake to the sound of a low murmur. Ewan was moving restlessly, his head thrashing on the pillow, his hands plucking at the thin blanket. He was muttering, his voice thick with delirium. "Too many eyes… the trees have eyes… can’t see the stars…" Peter was at his side in an instant. He took the cloth, which had grown warm, dipped it again in the basin of cool water, and laid it gently on Ewan's brow. "Shhh, Ewan," he whispered, his voice close to Ewan's ear. "You're alright. It's just me. It’s Peter. You’re safe." He wasn't sure if the words registered, but he repeated them like an incantation, a shield against the fever-dreams. He took one of Ewan’s hot, restless hands in his own. His grip was surprisingly strong, clinging to Peter’s as if he were a lifeline in a storm-tossed sea. Peter held on, an anchor in the dark.

Sometime in the deepest part of the night, when the only sound was the lonely rattle of a far-off tram, Ewan’s eyes opened. The fever-glaze was gone, replaced by a lucid exhaustion. He looked at Peter, at their joined hands, at the flickering fire, and then around the small, warm room. He seemed to be taking in the scene from a great distance, as if seeing it for the first time. His throat worked for a moment before he spoke, his voice a dry rasp. "You stayed." It wasn't a question. "Of course I stayed," Peter said, his own voice thick with sleeplessness. He felt a blush creep up his neck, a strange mix of shyness and pride. Ewan squeezed his hand, a faint but deliberate pressure. "My da," he said, his gaze fixed on the ceiling, "he used to say the only thing worse than being sick was being sick alone." He turned his head on the pillow to look at Peter, and in the faint firelight, his peat-smoke eyes were dark pools of a raw, unguarded emotion Peter had never seen before. "Thank you." The words were simple, scraped from the depths of his weariness, but they landed with the weight of a sacred vow.

The first hint of dawn began to bleed into the sky, turning the black of the window to a bruised, watery grey. The reality of the outside world, of the coming day, began to press at the edges of their small sanctuary. The shipyard. His own empty room. The questions. Peter felt a familiar knot of anxiety tighten in his stomach. He should go. He should slip back down the stairs before the building woke up, resume his post, maintain the fiction. But the thought of leaving Ewan, of letting the cold and the silence creep back into this room, was unbearable. He looked at Ewan, who seemed to have drifted into a true, healing sleep at last, his breathing deep and even, the tremors gone. The fever had broken. He couldn't leave him. Not yet. Making a decision that felt both insane and completely necessary, Peter gently disentangled his hand from Ewan's. He crept to the door, opened it a crack, and listened. The close was silent. He slipped out, his boots silent on the stone, and went not down, but up. To the top-floor washhouse. He soaked his own handkerchief in the cold, scummy water from the basin, then crept back down to his own floor. He unlocked his door, went inside for only a moment, and then re-emerged, locking it behind him. He returned to Ewan's room as a thief returns to the scene of a crime, his heart pounding. Back inside, he went to the window, the one that mirrored his own. He waited. Soon, he knew, Davie or one of the other men from the yard who lived nearby would pass, and seeing his dark window, would assume he was gone. Then, Peter took the damp handkerchief and, with a grim sense of purpose, began to rub it against his own face and neck, forcing a clammy, artificial chill onto his skin. He would not go to the shipyard. When Mrs Gable eventually knocked to ask after him, he would be sick. He would have the same fever that was sweeping the Gallowgate. He would build the wall higher, but this time, he would be on the same side of it as Ewan.The first hour of daylight was the longest of Peter’s life. He sat in the chair by Ewan’s bed, a conspirator in a crime that hadn’t yet been discovered, every sound from the close magnified a hundredfold. He heard the first of the shipyard men clattering down the stairs, their gruff voices and loud boots a familiar part of a morning he had chosen to betray. He heard the milkman’s clinking bottles, Mrs Gable’s door opening and closing on the floor below, the city waking up to a day he would not be a part of. With each sound, his stomach clenched. He was an absence in his own life, a ghost in his own room, a boy who had deliberately vanished from the world in order to exist more fully in this one small, fire-warmed space. Ewan slept on, oblivious, his breathing the only steady, reassuring rhythm in the tense, waiting silence.

The knock came just after eight, three sharp, brisk raps that were unmistakably Mrs Gable’s. It was not on Ewan’s door, but on his own, one floor below. Peter froze, his hand tightening on the arm of the chair. He heard her knock again, more insistently this time, followed by a pause. "Peter? Lad, you'll be late for the yard!" Her reedy voice, muffled by two floors, carried up the stairwell with perfect, dreadful clarity. He held his breath. He heard her tutting, a sound of mild exasperation, and then her footsteps retreating. He allowed himself a slow, shaky exhale. He had cleared the first hurdle. But he knew it was only a reprieve.

A half-hour later, the footsteps returned, slower this time, climbing past his own floor. They stopped directly outside Ewan's door. The knock, when it came, was softer, more hesitant. Ewan stirred, his brow furrowing in sleep. Peter was on his feet in an instant, his heart a frantic bird against his ribs. He crossed to the door and leaned his ear against the cold wood. "Mr Scott?" Mrs Gable's voice was gentle, laced with concern. "I know you're unwell, dear, but I'm worried about the lad below you. He's not gone to work and he's not answering his door. I just wanted to be sure he wasn't…" She let the thought hang, unfinished and grim. This was it. The performance. Peter took a deep, steadying breath, opened the door a crack, and peered out, blinking as if the weak light of the landing was a painful glare.

He let his shoulders slump, forcing a shiver into his frame. "Mrs Gable," he croaked, his voice a deliberately weak and scratchy imitation of Ewan's. He coughed, a dry, pathetic sound that scraped his throat. "I'm sorry. I think… I think I've got it too." He watched her face, a mask of practised misery fixed on his own. The landlady's sharp eyes softened with a mixture of sympathy and weary resignation. She peered past him into the gloom of the room, where Ewan was now sitting up in bed, looking pale and confused. "Oh, you poor lambs," she sighed, shaking her head. "The pair of you. It's a wicked flu. Well, at least you're not alone. One of you can fetch for the other." She looked from Peter's wan face to Ewan's shadowed one. "Is there anything I can get for you both? A bit of broth, perhaps?" Her gaze was kind, her concern genuine. There was no suspicion, only a tired acceptance of the tenement's communal miseries. The relief was so profound it made Peter feel dizzy. "No, thank you, Mrs Gable. We'll manage," he said, his voice barely a whisper. "Just need to sleep it off." He offered her a weak, grateful smile and slowly closed the door, leaning his forehead against the wood, his entire body trembling with the aftermath of the lie.

When he turned back into the room, Ewan was watching him, his expression a complex mixture of awe and alarm. He had swung his legs over the side of the bed, his bare feet on the cold floorboards. The fire had warmed the room enough that he was no longer shivering, and the lucid light of recovery was fully back in his eyes. "Peter," he said, his voice still rough but stronger now. "What in God's name have you done?" It wasn’t an accusation. It was a question born of pure disbelief. He gestured around the room, at the simmering pot, the neatly folded blanket, at Peter himself, standing there like a dishevelled, triumphant actor who had just walked off stage. "You can't just… not go to the yard. They'll sack you. You can't just move in here. What were you thinking?"

"I was thinking you were going to die alone in a cold room," Peter retorted, his own voice sharper than he intended, the residual adrenaline of the performance making him bold. "I was thinking that all our cleverness and our quiet and our rules meant nothing if I let that happen." He walked over to the fire and busied himself with the poker, prodding the coals with unnecessary force. "So I stopped being clever. I left my door locked from the inside and I came here." He looked over his shoulder at Ewan. "Mrs Gable thinks I'm sick in my own room. Now she thinks we're both sick, and we're looking after each other. Like pals." He spat the last word out, a bitter echo of the fear that had driven them apart. But here, in the safety of their shared confinement, the word was not a disguise; it was a shield. It was the story they had sold the world, and for now, the world had bought it. The sheer, insane genius of it was just beginning to dawn on him. They hadn't just built a wall. Peter had found a door, and he'd locked it from the inside.For a long moment, Ewan just stared, his mind trying to catch up with the sheer, breathtaking audacity of what Peter had done. The carefully constructed fortress of caution he had built around himself, rule by painstaking rule, had just been stormed not by an enemy, but by this quiet, determined boy with shipyard dust in his hair and a strategist’s mind hidden behind a poet’s eyes. He should have been angry. He should have been terrified. The risk was monumental, a gamble that could bring the whole flimsy structure of their lives crashing down. But as he looked at Peter, standing there flushed with defiance and the heat from the hearth, a slow, unfamiliar warmth spread through his own chest, a warmth that had nothing to do with the fading fever. A laugh, a real one, unperformed and incredulous, bubbled up from deep inside him. It was a rusty, cracked sound, but it was genuine.

"You're mad," Ewan said, the words catching in his throat. He shook his head slowly, a dawning smile finally breaking across his face. "Completely and utterly mad." He pushed himself up straighter, the strength returning to his limbs now that the immediate threat of solitude had been so thoroughly vanquished. He looked around the room, at the small fire burning brightly, the scent of lemon and steam in the air, the general air of order that Peter had imposed on his bachelor's chaos. It felt less like his own grim room and more like a corner of the world that had been claimed and defended. "And Mrs Gable just… believed you?"

"Why wouldn't she?" Peter replied, a spark of pride in his voice. "It's the perfect story. The whole street is sick. Why not us? And everyone knows it's good to have a pal." He leaned against the mantelpiece, the firelight catching the determined set of his jaw. "Now she'll leave us alone. She might even leave us broth." The pragmatism of it, the simple, devastating logic, struck Ewan with the force of a revelation. He had been so focused on hiding, on being invisible, that he had never considered the power of a plausible, visible lie. Peter hadn't built a higher wall; he'd created a smoke screen, a piece of theatre so mundane and believable that no one would ever think to look behind the curtain.

And so began their period of stolen time. Their world shrank to the four walls of Ewan’s room, and in doing so, it became infinite. The first day, Ewan was still weak, and Peter played the role of caregiver with a solemn dedication. Just as he’d predicted, a pot of thin, salty mutton broth appeared outside the door mid-morning, a testament to Mrs Gable’s kindness and the success of their deception. They shared it, sitting on the edge of the bed, a quiet, conspiratorial glee passing between them with every spoonful. The constant, low-level fear that had been Peter’s companion for weeks was replaced by a humming, vigilant contentment. He was no longer waiting for a signal or dreading a footstep; he was inside the fortress, guarding the gate.

As Ewan’s strength returned over the next day, the dynamic shifted from patient and nurse to that of two people simply sharing a life. The enforced proximity, which should have been awkward, was instead a catalyst for a new kind of intimacy. They moved around each other in the small space with an unconscious, fluid grace, their shoulders brushing as one tended the fire while the other made tea. They talked. They talked for hours, filling the silence they had so long endured with the stories of their lives. Peter spoke of his childhood in a fishing village on the coast, of his mother who had loved books and his father who had been lost to the sea, the reason he’d come to the city to find work that was tied to solid ground. He confessed his dreams of one day seeing the world beyond the pages, of finding a place where the air wasn’t thick with coal.

In return, Ewan, his hands finally steady enough to pick up his carving tools, began to unlock his own past. He told Peter about the birds. Each one had a name and a story. He picked up the half-finished hawk, its feathers intricately detailed. "This one's for my brother, Cal," he said, his voice soft. "He's up in the Highlands. Always said I saw things he couldn't, that I could find the bird inside the wood." He explained that the carving was the only thing that quieted his mind, the only way he knew how to pray. He spoke of his own departure from his small town, not of forestry work, but of a quiet, brutal shunning after a rumour started, a story about him and another boy that had spread like wildfire. He’d left to protect his family from the talk, trading the vast, open sky for the anonymity of the Gallowgate’s grimy canyons. Peter listened, his heart aching with a fierce, protective tenderness. He looked at the flock of silent, wooden birds, and he understood. This wasn't just a hobby; it was an act of survival, a way of populating his loneliness with beautiful, wild things that could not be caged by the judgment of others.

On the third night, the fever was a distant memory. The city outside was quiet, the fire had burned down to a deep, pulsating bed of embers that filled the room with a soft, red glow. They sat on the floor, their backs against the side of the bed, sharing the last of Ewan’s tobacco in a hand-rolled cigarette that passed between them. The conversation had dwindled, the stories told, leaving a comfortable, humming silence in their wake. Peter watched the smoke curl from Ewan’s lips and vanish into the shadows. He felt Ewan’s gaze on him, steady and intense in the dim light. The constant physical closeness of the past days had re-calibrated his senses; he was acutely aware of the warmth of Ewan’s shoulder pressed against his own, the rhythm of his breathing. Ewan reached out, his fingers tracing the line of Peter's jaw, a touch that was no longer tentative or questioning. It was a touch that knew its destination. He leaned in, and the kiss was nothing like the desperate, frantic ones on the rooftop. It was slow, and deep, and sure. It tasted of tobacco and woodsmoke and the quiet triumph of their shared sanctuary. It was not a kiss of defiance against the world, but a kiss of coming home.The world, when Peter woke, came to him slowly, filtered through the unfamiliar warmth of another body. He was curled on his side, his back pressed against the solid wall of Ewan’s chest, one of Ewan’s arms draped possessively over his waist. The grey morning light, usually so accusatory, was soft and forgiving as it filtered through the grimy windowpane, illuminating dust motes dancing in a lazy column. For the first time since coming to this city, Peter felt the quiet not as an absence, but as a presence. It was the soft sound of Ewan’s breathing in his ear, the gentle ticking of a clock he hadn't noticed before, the distant, muffled rumble of Glasgow starting its day. He lay perfectly still, memorising the feeling of Ewan’s hand resting on his stomach, the rough texture of the wool blanket, the faint scent of woodsmoke that clung to the pillow. This was not the desperate, fever-pitch of the rooftop, nor the stolen, fearful moments on the stairs. This was something else entirely. It was a quiet, profound, and terrifyingly normal morning.

Their stolen days bled into a week, a small lifetime lived within the confines of a single room. The pretence of sickness became their new reality, a shield that allowed for a fragile, impossible domesticity to bloom. Peter learned the landscape of Ewan’s body as intimately as he knew the pages of his favourite books, and Ewan learned the rhythms of Peter’s thoughts, anticipating his moods from the way he turned a page or stared into the fire. They existed in a bubble of shared tasks and easy silence. Mornings were for brewing strong tea and sharing a piece of toast, their movements a choreographed dance in the cramped space. In the afternoons, Ewan would sit by the window, the light falling on his hands as he carved, the soft scrape and whisper of his knife a counterpoint to Peter reading aloud from his book of sea voyages and distant lands. Peter’s voice would fill the room with tales of open water and star-filled skies, and Ewan would make the stories real, coaxing a diving gannet or a soaring albatross from a block of unassuming limewood. It was a perfect, self-contained world, and the knowledge of its impermanence made every moment unbearably precious.

The first tremor that shook their sanctuary came not as a knock, but as a thin, white sliver sliding under the door. It was a Tuesday morning, a full ten days since Peter had last set foot in the shipyard. They both saw it at the same time, a pale rectangle against the dark floorboards. An official-looking envelope from the Gallowgate postal service, misdelivered to Ewan’s door instead of his own. Ewan retrieved it, his expression hardening as he recognised the shipyard’s insignia stamped in the corner. He handed it to Peter without a word. Peter’s hands, which had been so steady making their breakfast minutes before, trembled as he broke the seal. The language was formal, cold, and final. His position had been terminated due to unexplained absence. His final wages could be collected from the foreman’s office. The paper felt heavy in his hand, a death sentence for the life he had known. The noise of the shipyard, the security of the wage packet, the grim purpose of his days—all of it, gone. He looked up at Ewan, the small room suddenly feeling like a cage, the walls closing in. The world they had so carefully kept at bay had just kicked down the door.

"I knew this would happen," Peter said, his voice hollow. He sank onto the edge of the bed, the letter crumpled in his fist. "It's over. I've got nothing, Ewan. No job. No money coming in." The reality of his recklessness crashed over him, a cold, sickening wave. Their week of stolen time had been bought at the cost of his entire future. All he had was this room, and this room wasn’t even his. He felt a familiar, desperate panic rising, the old fear that he would be swept away, lost in the city's unforgiving currents. He had flown too close to the sun, and now he was falling, the wax of his wings melting away.

Ewan crossed the room and knelt in front of him, taking the crumpled letter from his hand and smoothing it out on his knee. He looked not at the words, but at Peter’s face, his peat-smoke eyes serious and calm. "No," he said, his voice low and firm, a steady anchor in the storm of Peter’s panic. "It's not over. It's just changed." He reached for the table and picked up the hawk he had been carving, the one for his brother. It was nearly finished, its wings perfectly poised, its wooden eyes sharp and focused. "This city, this yard… it was never your sky, Peter. It was a cage you happened to find food in. I told you once, there's always somewhere else to fly to." He held the hawk out. It wasn't a gift; it was a promise, an argument. "My brother, Cal. He works a timber plantation, north of Aberdeen. They're always looking for men. Hard work, but the air is clean and the pay is honest. And the foremen don't care about anything but how well you can swing an axe." He looked Peter straight in the eye, his grip tightening on the wooden bird. "They don't care who you share your roof with."

The proposition hung in the air, audacious and terrifying. To leave Glasgow. To abandon the only life he knew, grim as it was, for a place he’d only read about on maps. It was one thing to dream of escape from the pages of a book, another entirely to pack a bag and walk out into the cold reality of it. It was the sea calling to his father all over again, a siren song of the unknown. But then he looked at Ewan, kneeling before him, offering not just a half-formed dream but a tangible plan, a destination. He looked at the life they had managed to carve out in this tiny, besieged room—the shared meals, the stories, the quiet understanding, the breathtaking normalcy of waking up in Ewan’s arms. The thought of losing that, of returning to his own cold, empty room, of watching Ewan become just a shape in a window again—that was a fear greater than any unknown. It was the difference between falling and flying.

"What about… all this?" Peter asked, gesturing vaguely at the room, the flock of birds, the small universe Ewan had built. Ewan followed his gaze, a flicker of sadness in his eyes. "They're just wood," he said softly. "The real birds are out there." He placed the hawk into Peter’s hands. Its weight was solid, real. A plan. A future. Peter curled his fingers around it, the smooth, carved feathers pressing into his palm. He took a deep breath, the air tasting of hope and fear in equal measure, and he nodded. "Alright," he said, the word a quiet vow. "When do we leave?" A slow, brilliant smile spread across Ewan’s face, the real, lopsided smile that had started it all. He stood up, pulling Peter to his feet with him. "As soon as we've sold what we can and packed what we can't," he said, his voice alive with a sudden, fierce energy. "We leave at night. We'll be ghosts, gone by morning." They stood in the centre of the room, no longer a sanctuary but a launching pad, the shipyard's dismissal letter lying discarded on the floor like a shed skin. Together, they turned and looked out the window, not at each other's separate worlds, but at the sprawling, grimy city below, a place that had almost broken them. It was not their home. It was just a place they were leaving.The decision, once made, electrified the air in the small room. The lethargy of their false sickness and the paralysis of fear were burned away by a sudden, fierce blaze of purpose. Their sanctuary was no longer a place to hide, but a temporary camp from which to plan a great expedition. The world, which had been a threat to be kept out, was now a thing to be navigated, conquered. Ewan, imbued with a restless energy that seemed to flow back into his limbs with the plan's formation, hauled a dusty tin trunk from beneath his bed. Its metal feet scraped a harsh, decisive line across the floorboards, a sound that was not an ending, but a beginning. He clicked open the rusted latches, the noise echoing in the quiet room. "Right," he said, his voice crisp and clear, a captain’s voice. "Inventory. We take what we can carry, what has a purpose. Everything else is a ghost. We leave the ghosts behind."

The first sacrifice was the flock. For two hours, Ewan sat on the floor, his back straight, and presided over the dispersal of his wooden children. He handled each one with a tender reverence, his calloused fingers tracing the lines he had so patiently carved into them. He was not just packing; he was saying goodbye. Peter watched in silence, his heart aching with a shared sense of loss. He understood that these were not just objects; they were the silent companions of Ewan’s lonely years, the population of his solitude. Ewan set aside three small figures: the nearly-finished hawk for his brother, a tiny, perfect wren which he pressed into Peter’s palm without a word, and a sleek, diving otter that he tucked deep into his own satchel. The rest—gulls and finches, owls and blackbirds—were wrapped carefully in old newspaper and arranged in a cardboard box. "There’s a man near the Barras," Ewan explained, his voice carefully neutral. "Deals in oddities. He knows my work. He’ll give us a fair price." He didn’t look at Peter as he spoke, his gaze fixed on the box, and Peter knew that a fair price for such a thing did not exist.

They walked to the dealer’s shop through a part of the city Peter had never seen, a labyrinth of narrow streets where the tenements leaned in so close they seemed to be whispering secrets to one another. The shop was a dusty cave of forgotten things, smelling of decaying paper and furniture polish. The dealer, a small, bird-like man with spectacles perched on the end of his nose, unwrapped each carving with greedy, appreciative fingers. He hummed and nodded, holding them up to the weak light. The haggling was brief and quiet. Ewan stood firm, his jaw set, and the dealer, sensing a resolve that went beyond mere commerce, eventually agreed. They left the shop with a thin sheaf of banknotes in Ewan’s pocket, the weight of the money feeling insignificant compared to the sudden lightness of the box he no longer carried. As they walked away, Peter glanced back and saw the dealer placing one of the gulls in the shop window, its wings spread, forever poised for a flight it would never take.

The next trial fell to Peter alone. He had to return to the shipyard, a final descent into the inferno to claim the wages that would fund their escape. Ewan had wanted to go with him, but Peter refused. This was his ghost to lay to rest. Walking through the familiar, grimy streets towards the yard felt like walking into a dream he’d already woken from. The deafening roar reached him blocks away, a sound that no longer filled him with dread, but with a strange, detached pity. He was an outsider now, a tourist in his own former life. At the gate, he saw Davie, sharing a cigarette with another man. The old riveter saw him, and his weathered face registered a flicker of surprise, then something else, something softer. He ambled over, his expression unreadable. "Heard you were down with the fever, lad," Davie said, his voice a low rumble. He looked Peter up and down, taking in his pale face and the dark circles under his eyes, the genuine signs of sleeplessness and anxiety that passed perfectly for the lingering effects of illness. "Still look half-drowned. You should be at your bed." There was no anger, no judgment, only a gruff, paternal concern. "I’m away, Davie," Peter said, the words feeling momentous. "Leaving the city." Davie nodded slowly, as if he’d been expecting it. "Aye," he said, and clapped a heavy hand on Peter’s shoulder. "Some birds aren't meant for this kind of cage. Good luck to you, son." And with that, he turned and walked back to his companion, the conversation over. The foreman in the office was less sentimental. He was a creature of ledgers and timetables, and Peter was merely a name to be crossed off a list. He slid the small brown envelope of wages across the counter without meeting Peter’s eye, already turning his attention to the next piece of paperwork. Peter took the money, the tangible price of his freedom, and walked out of the shipyard gates without a backward glance, the shriek of metal being tortured into shape fading behind him for the last time.

Their final night in Glasgow was quiet and purposeful. With the money from the birds and Peter’s wages secured in the tin trunk, they packed their few belongings. Peter discarded his oil-stained shipyard clothes in a corner, leaving them like a shed skin. He packed his handful of books, his clean shirts, and the small wooden wren Ewan had given him, which he wrapped in a spare sock for protection. The room, stripped of most of its carvings and their personal effects, felt large and empty, a hollowed-out space that held only the echo of the life they had lived within it. After a last meal of bread and cheese, they stood together at the window. The back court below was a slick, black mirror, reflecting nothing. In the tenement opposite, Peter’s own window was a dark, vacant eye. For months, he had stared across this chasm, projecting all his loneliness and longing onto the figure on the other side. Now, that figure was standing beside him, his arm warm and solid around Peter’s shoulders, and together they looked out at the empty space. "Funny," Peter whispered. "I used to think that was the whole world." Ewan pulled him closer. "We were just reading the map," he said. "Now we go find the place." They waited as the tenement settled, as the last lights blinked out, until the only sound was the wind sighing in the chimney pots. The time had come. With Ewan carrying the trunk and Peter his own satchel, they opened the door one last time. The air in the close was cold and smelled, as always, of damp and boiled cabbage. It was the scent of a life they were leaving forever. They descended the stairs, each step a silent farewell, their boots making no sound on the worn stone. They passed Peter’s floor, and he did not look at his own door. They passed Mrs Gable's, and imagined her sleeping, oblivious to the flight of her two sick birds. At the main door, Ewan paused and set down the trunk. He looked at Peter, a question in his eyes. Peter simply nodded. Together, they put their shoulders to the heavy wooden door and pushed it open, stepping out into the cold, empty street. A light drizzle was beginning to fall, but it was cleansing now, washing the grime from the air as they turned their backs on the Gallowgate and began to walk towards the east, towards the distant promise of the sea and the clean, sharp scent of pine.The walk through the sleeping city was a journey through a graveyard of their own making. Every street corner, every shadowed close, was a monument to a life they had just buried.
