They walked for half a mile down a narrow side road until they spotted it: a derelict stone barn, its roof sagging in the middle but mostly intact, its doorway a gaping black mouth. It was not a home, but it was a reprieve. Inside, the air was thick with the ghost-scent of old hay and livestock. As Ewan set the trunk down with a weary thud, a handful of startled pigeons burst from the rafters and fled into the twilight. They made their camp in a dry corner, the trunk serving as their table. They ate bread and hard cheese, the simple food tasting better than any hot meal Peter had ever had. As the last of the light died, leaving them in a profound, starless dark, they unrolled their single blanket and huddled together for warmth, their backs against the cold stone wall. The world outside was vast and wild and unknown, but here, in the dark, with the solid weight of Ewan beside him, Peter felt a sense of safety more absolute than any he had ever known.

Peter woke to a cold so profound it felt like a solid thing, a block of ice he was encased in. It was a different cold from the city’s damp, insidious chill that seeped into the lungs; this was a clean, sharp, absolute cold that bit at his exposed cheeks and turned his breath into a cloud of white vapour. He was pressed against Ewan’s back, their shared blanket a pitifully thin barrier against the pre-dawn frost that had silvered the broken flagstones of the barn floor. For a moment, disoriented, he thought he was back in his room in the Gallowgate, the cold a familiar enemy. But then he smelled it: not soot and damp stone, but the rich, loamy scent of earth, the ghost of hay, and the sharp tang of frost on sleeping fields. He was free. And this was the price of it. He shifted slightly, and Ewan stirred, a low grunt escaping him as he pulled the blanket tighter around them, his arm instinctively tightening around Peter’s waist. In the deep, resonant stillness, Peter could hear the rustle of a mouse in the straw and, far away, the lonely cry of a curlew. The fear was still there, a small, cold stone in his gut, but it was overshadowed by a feeling so vast and new he had no name for it, a feeling of being utterly alive in the immensity of the world.

Their morning ablutions were a spartan affair at a cattle trough in a nearby field, the water so cold it made Peter’s teeth ache and his skin sting. They shared the last of their bread, which was stale, and a piece of hard cheese, their hands blue and clumsy with the cold. Yet, there was an easy grace to their movements, a wordless communication that had been forged in the crucible of their confined week. Ewan broke the cheese with his thumbs and handed half to Peter. Peter uncorked their water bottle and passed it to Ewan. These simple acts of sharing felt more significant than any grand declaration, a testament to their new reality. They were a single unit of two, adrift in the world, their survival dependent on this quiet, instinctive partnership. Ewan, his face etched with weariness but his eyes clear and focused, studied the crumpled map he had bought with the last of his own money before they left. He traced a line with his finger, his brow furrowed in concentration. "There's a main road about two miles east of here," he said, his voice a low rumble in the cold air. "Goes all the way to Aberdeen. If we can get a ride on that, we'll be there by nightfall." He folded the map and looked at Peter, a silent question in his eyes. *Are you ready?* Peter simply nodded, pulling his thin coat tighter around him, and they set off, their breath pluming in front of them as they walked into the rising sun.

The walk was harder than Peter had imagined. The road was a muddy track, and the two miles felt more like ten, his city-softened muscles protesting with every step. But the landscape was a constant, unfolding miracle that distracted him from the ache in his legs. He saw hills that were the colour of old tweed, swaths of dark, brooding forest, and burns that chattered over stones, the water a startling, clear amber. He was seeing the country that Ewan had spoken of, the world that had shaped him. He watched Ewan stride ahead, his long-legged gait eating up the ground, his posture relaxed and confident. Here, Ewan was not the furtive, watchful man of the Gallowgate; he was a native, his senses attuned to the wind and the sky. He pointed out the distant shape of a buzzard circling high above, identified the tracks of a fox in the mud, and named the trees that clustered in the hollows. It was a language Peter didn't speak, but he listened with a hungry intensity, feeling his understanding of Ewan deepening with every shared observation. The pine-scented man from the tenement was finally in his forest, and Peter was seeing him whole for the first time.

They reached the main road, a wider, busier artery, and the waiting began again. This time, it was a lorry hauling livestock, the air around it thick with the smell of the animals and the road. The driver was a wiry, older man with a suspicious squint who barely spoke, but he was heading to Aberdeen and, for the price of one of Peter’s last few shillings, he grunted and nodded them into the cab. The journey was loud and rattling, the cab filled with the driver’s tuneless whistling and the constant, mournful complaints of the sheep in the back. The driver’s silence was more unnerving than the last one’s garrulousness; his eyes kept flicking to them in the rearview mirror, a silent, ongoing assessment. Peter sat rigidly, hyper-aware of his hand resting on the seat close to Ewan’s, conscious of the easy way Ewan leaned his shoulder against the cab door. He felt the old city fear prickle at him, the ingrained habit of hiding. But Ewan seemed oblivious. He stared out at the passing landscape, a calm, proprietary look on his face, as if he owned every hill and river they passed. When the driver finally dropped them at a desolate roundabout on the outskirts of Aberdeen, Peter felt a wave of relief so strong his knees almost buckled as he jumped down from the cab.

Aberdeen was a shock. It was a city, but a city made of granite, not soot-stained sandstone. The buildings were grey and glittering, hard-edged and severe under a sky that was scoured clean by a relentless wind blowing in from the North Sea. The air tasted of salt and fish, a stark, bracing contrast to Glasgow’s thick, industrial fug. They were exhausted, bone-weary and hungry, the last of their money having gone to the lorry driver. The reality of their situation hit Peter with renewed force. They had made it, but they had arrived with nothing but the clothes on their backs, a tin trunk, and the name of a timber plantation somewhere up the coast. The brief euphoria of the journey gave way to the cold, hard facts of survival. He saw a baker’s shop, its window piled high with golden rolls and pastries, and his stomach cramped with a hunger so sharp it was almost a pain. He looked at Ewan, a question and a flicker of his old panic in his eyes. Ewan followed his gaze to the bakery, and his jaw tightened. "Cal's place is another six miles up the coast," he said, his voice low. "We walk. We'll be there before it's fully dark." He shouldered the strap of his satchel, his expression grim. "No more stopping. We get there." There was no choice. They turned their backs on the city’s tantalising warmth and started the long walk north, the roar of the unseen sea growing louder with every step.

The final six miles were a pilgrimage. The road clung to the coastline, a narrow track with the furious, grey sea on one side and a rising wall of dark, dense forest on the other. The wind was a physical force, tearing at their clothes and trying to push them from the path. It carried the scream of gulls and the deep, percussive boom of waves crashing against rocks below. This was a different world entirely, a place of raw, elemental power that made the city’s dangers seem small and petty. Peter leaned into the wind, his head down, his body a single, aching protest. He was running on nothing but fumes and the sheer, stubborn refusal to be the one who fell behind. He focused on the steady rhythm of Ewan’s boots on the gravel in front of him, using it as a metronome to drive his own exhausted legs forward. Just as he felt he could not take another step, Ewan stopped. He had paused at a gap in the stone wall, his hand resting on the top stone, his gaze fixed on the land that sloped down towards the sea. Peter came to a halt beside him, panting, and followed his gaze.

Below them, stretching for as far as the eye could see, was the forest. It was a vast, dark green ocean of pine trees, their ranks marching down the rugged hillsides right to the edge of the cliffs, where the sea gnawed at the land. The sheer scale of it was breathtaking. Through the dense canopy, Peter could see cleared tracks and the distant, glinting roofs of a few low buildings clustered in a hollow near the shore. A plume of woodsmoke rose from a chimney, a thin, vertical line of grey against the deep green, a sign of life in the immense wilderness. The air was thick with the scent Ewan had always carried with him, a powerful, intoxicating perfume of pine resin, salt, and damp earth. This was it. This was the place from the stories, the source of the carved birds, the heart of Ewan’s secret world. It was wilder, bigger, and more intimidating than anything Peter could have imagined. Ewan turned to him, his face weathered by the wind, his eyes alight with a fierce, proprietary pride. "Well," he said, his voice almost carried away by the wind. "This is it, Peter. This is the garden." Peter looked from the vast, roaring sea to the endless, whispering forest, then back to the man standing beside him. He was exhausted, hungry, and had not a penny to his name. But as he stood there, with the wooden wren safe in his pocket and Ewan's solid presence beside him, he felt not fear, but a quiet, trembling sense of arrival. He had walked off the edge of his old map and, impossibly, had found his way home.

The descent from the road was a journey into another element. The wind that had scoured the cliffs above softened to a soughing whisper as they entered the shelter of the pines. The path was a treacherous track of slick, dark earth and tangled roots, and Peter, clumsy with exhaustion, stumbled several times, his hands brushing against bark that was rough and sticky with resin. The air grew thick and cool, heavy with the powerful, cathedral-like scent of a million pine needles, a scent so pure and overwhelming it seemed to scour the last of the city’s pollution from his lungs. The roar of the sea faded, replaced by the creak and groan of the trees, the distant chatter of a hidden burn, and the soft crunch of their own boots on the forest floor. Peter watched Ewan move ahead of him, and it was like watching a man step back into his own skin. The last vestiges of the city’s coiled tension fell away from his shoulders. He moved with an easy, silent grace, his head up, reading the signs of the forest as easily as Peter would read a printed page. He belonged here, and the rightness of it was as absolute and undeniable as the towering trees around them.

The settlement appeared suddenly in a wide clearing, a small cluster of rugged, functional buildings that seemed to have grown from the earth itself. There were long, low bunkhouses built from rough-hewn logs, a larger structure from which the scent of cooking food emanated, and an open-sided workshop where the air was hazy with sawdust and the clean, sharp smell of freshly cut wood. A few men, their faces weathered and bearded, their clothes stained with sweat and resin, stopped what they were doing to watch their approach. Their stillness was unnerving, their gazes direct and assessing, utterly different from the furtive, sideways glances of the Gallowgate. They looked at Ewan, and a flicker of recognition, of surprise, passed among them. They looked at Peter, and their faces were blank, unreadable masks. There was no welcome here, but no immediate hostility either; just the patient, watchful curiosity of men who lived by their own rules in a world far removed from any Peter had ever known.

A man emerged from the largest cabin, wiping his hands on a greasy rag tucked into his belt. He was built on the same generous scale as Ewan, with the same broad shoulders, but where Ewan was a wanderer, this man was an anchor. His hair was a darker shade of brown, his face leaner, carved by wind and work into something harder and more severe. He stopped dead when he saw them, the rag in his hands stilled. For a long moment, the two brothers just looked at each other across the clearing, the twenty yards between them filled with years of unspoken history. "Thought a bad penny always turned up," the man said, his voice a low, gravelly rumble that was an echo of Ewan’s own. Ewan’s mouth quirked into a ghost of his lopsided smile. "Only when it's spent, Cal," he replied. He took the last few steps forward and gestured with his head towards Peter, who had come to a halt a few feet behind him, feeling intensely out of place. "This is Peter," Ewan said, the introduction simple, declarative. "He’s with me."

Cal’s eyes, a paler, flintier grey than Ewan's, shifted to Peter. He subjected him to a long, slow appraisal that travelled from his worn-out city boots to his pale, exhausted face and back again. It was not an unkind look, but it was utterly devoid of sentiment. It was the look a man gives a piece of timber to judge its strength, or the sky to judge the coming weather. Peter felt himself being weighed and measured, and found wanting. He stood his ground, his chin up, his hand unconsciously checking for the small, hard shape of the wooden wren in his pocket. The silence stretched, thick and uncomfortable. Finally, Cal’s gaze moved back to Ewan, and a silent, lightning-fast conversation seemed to pass between them, an exchange of questions and answers that needed no words. At last, Cal gave a short, sharp nod, his judgment made. "He looks half-dead from the cold," he said, his voice flat. "Both of you. Get inside. Annie’s made stew." He turned his back on them without another word and strode back towards the cabin, the dismissal and the invitation delivered in the same brusque, practical gesture.

The inside of the cookhouse was a haven of warmth and light. A huge, cast-iron stove dominated one wall, radiating a heat that felt like a physical blessing, and the air was thick with the rich, savoury smell of roasting meat and onions. A long, scarred wooden table, big enough to seat twenty men, ran down the centre of the room. A stout, grey-haired woman with kind eyes and flour on her forearms—Annie, Peter presumed—nodded at them as Cal ladled two deep bowls of stew from a cavernous pot. They sat at the end of the long table, and Peter ate with a ravenous, desperate speed, the thick, hot stew a miracle in his throat. It was simple food, just meat and barley and root vegetables, but it was the most delicious thing he had ever tasted. The warmth spread through him, chasing out the last of the cold, and with it, a wave of exhaustion so profound it was all he could do to keep his head from falling forward into the empty bowl. He had made it. They had made it. The sheer, impossible reality of it was as overwhelming as the food and the heat.

After the bowls were empty, Cal sat down opposite them with a mug of black, steaming tea. He looked at Ewan, his expression less guarded now that the duties of a host had been fulfilled. "So," he began, his voice low. "The city finally spit you out?" Ewan leaned back, stretching his long legs under the table. He didn't recount the fever, or the hiding, or the desperate flight. He distilled the entire complex tragedy into a few, spare words. "The work dried up," he said. "It was time for a change of air." Cal nodded slowly, accepting the edited version. He knew his brother. He didn't need the details, only the truth that lay beneath them. He took a long sip of his tea, his flinty eyes moving to Peter once more. "We can always use another pair of hands, if he's not afraid of the work. There's an empty bunk in the east cabin. You can share it." He said it casually, as if it were the most natural thing in the world. "Sawmill starts at six. Can you handle an axe, Peter?" The direct question, the casual offer of a shared space, a shared life, all delivered in the same practical, no-nonsense tone. Peter looked at Ewan, who gave him a barely perceptible nod, and then he met Cal’s gaze directly. "I can learn," he said, his voice hoarse but steady. And with that simple exchange, the final brick of their new life clicked into place.

Cal led them from the cookhouse into the biting night air. The sudden cold was a shock after the fug of the stove, and Peter drew his thin coat tighter, the warmth of the stew a fading memory in his belly. The stars overhead were a brilliant, scattered dust of ice, a sight so vast and clear it made him feel dizzy. Their destination was a long, low building identical to the others, its log walls dark against the frosted ground. Cal pushed open the heavy plank door, and a wall of scent hit them: the dense, animal smell of sleeping men, of damp wool, sawdust, and the sharp, clean bite of pine sap that seemed to have permeated the very wood of the structure. The interior was a cavern of shadows, a single lantern at the far end casting long, dancing shapes. A row of rough-hewn bunk beds lined each wall, each a small territory of rumpled blankets and scant possessions. A chorus of snores and heavy breathing rose and fell in the gloom. It was a space stripped of all privacy, a communal den built for the sole purpose of rest after labour.

"Bunk in the far corner's free," Cal said, his voice a low rumble that didn't disturb the sleeping men. "It's wider. Should fit the two of you." He turned to leave, then paused, his hand on the door. "The bell rings at five. Breakfast is at half-past. Sawmill starts at six. Don't be late." Then he was gone, pulling the door shut behind him, leaving them standing in the near-darkness, the casual weight of his words settling around Peter like a heavy blanket. *Should fit the two of you.* It wasn't a question or a judgment. It was a simple, practical statement of fact, as mundane as the starting time for the sawmill. There was one empty bunk and two men. The solution was obvious. In this world, driven by the hard logic of work and weather, their secret was not a secret at all, but a simple matter of logistics. A wave of relief so profound it felt like a physical impact washed over Peter, and for a moment he had to steady himself against the central beam, the sheer, unassuming acceptance of it all more disarming than any shouted accusation could ever have been.

They found the bunk in the corner, a wide platform with a mattress stuffed thick with straw that rustled as Ewan threw their satchels onto it. Cal had left two coarse, heavy wool blankets folded at the foot. As they stripped off their damp outer layers in the frigid air, the momentousness of the simple act struck Peter with full force. They were not hiding in the dark, stealing a moment of desperate intimacy. They were simply two men preparing for bed at the end of a long day, their place in this small, rough world sanctioned and defined. When they finally slid under the blankets, the shared space felt both impossibly vast and deeply comforting. The straw-filled mattress was lumpy, the blankets smelled faintly of sheep, but the solid, radiating warmth of Ewan’s body next to his was the most luxurious thing Peter had ever felt. He curled on his side, his back pressed against Ewan’s chest, and felt an arm slide around his waist, pulling him close. Exhaustion, deep and absolute, claimed him instantly. He fell into a profound, dreamless sleep, anchored by the weight of the man beside him and the symphony of the forest outside—the whisper of wind in the pines and the distant, rhythmic roar of the sea.

The bell was a brutal, jarring clang that shattered the darkness. For a confused second, Peter thought it was the shriek of metal from the shipyard, a sound from a past life. Then the cold hit him, and the chorus of groans and curses from the other men as they stirred from their bunks. His body was a single, unified protest of aches. Muscles he hadn't known he possessed screamed in rebellion from the long walk. Ewan was already moving, swinging his legs out of the bunk with an economy of motion that spoke of long familiarity with such mornings. He saw Peter grimacing as he tried to sit up and tossed him a thick, felted wool shirt. "Put this on," he said, his voice a low rasp. "It gets colder before the sun is properly up. And your city boots won't last a day. I'll find you a spare pair." The advice was practical, devoid of sentiment, but it was a lifeline. In the dim, smoky light of the newly-lit lanterns, Peter watched the other men pull on heavy boots and thick trousers, their movements slow and deliberate, conserving energy for the day ahead. This was his new life: a bell in the dark, a borrowed shirt, and a day of labour he was utterly unprepared for.

Cal was true to his word. After a quick, silent breakfast of thick, hot porridge and black tea, he led Peter not to the sawmill, but to the edge of the clearing where a dozen enormous pine trees lay like felled giants. He handed Peter a felling axe, its handle worn smooth with use, its head a heavy, wicked-looking wedge of steel. "The yard work made your arms strong, but this is different," Cal said, his tone that of a teacher, not a tyrant. "It's about rhythm, not brute force. Your job is limbing. Strip every branch from these trunks, clean to the wood. Stack the branches by size. The small stuff for Annie's stove, the thick stuff for the charcoal kilns. Watch the others. And for God's sake, mind your footing. This ground is treacherous." He demonstrated a single, perfect swing, the axe head biting deep into the base of a thick branch, shearing it off with a sharp crack. The motion was fluid, powerful, and deceptively easy. Then he left Peter alone with a fallen tree that looked as long as a Gallowgate street.

The first hour was a lesson in humility. The axe felt like a clumsy, unwieldy club in Peter’s hands. His swings were awkward, either glancing off the resilient branches or biting in too deep, jarring his arms and shoulders with every mistimed blow. The shipyard had been about noise and fire, the taming of molten metal in a confined, deafening space. This was a battle against something organic and obstinate, fought in the cold, open air. The other men worked around him, their movements a blur of terrifying efficiency. He could feel their silent judgment, the occasional pause in their own work to watch the clumsy efforts of the newcomer. Once, he lost his grip entirely, the axe flying from his hands and burying itself in the soft earth a few feet away. A low chuckle rippled from a nearby pair of workers, and the shame was a hot, stinging flush on his cold cheeks. He wanted the ground to swallow him. But then he saw Ewan, working on a parallel tree, who caught his eye and gave a slight, almost imperceptible shake of his head, a silent command: *Ignore them. Keep going.* Peter retrieved the axe, his jaw set in a hard line, and forced himself to focus, not on the men, but on the tree, on the memory of Cal’s perfect, fluid swing.

At mid-day, Annie appeared with a cart, dispensing thick sandwiches of bread and cold meat, and a huge metal churn of hot, sweet tea. The men dropped their tools and gathered, eating quickly and talking in low, guttural bursts about timber yields and a predicted change in the weather. Peter found a spot on a log beside Ewan, his hands so stiff and raw he could barely hold his sandwich. He had blisters forming on both palms, angry red welts that promised a world of pain to come. Ewan took one of his hands, turning it over to inspect the damage with a practiced eye. "You're gripping too tight," he said, his voice quiet, for Peter’s ears only. "You're fighting the axe. Let its weight do the work for you. Guide it, don't force it." He pulled a small tin of foul-smelling, greenish salve from his pocket—the same one he'd used on his own hands—and wordlessly began to rub it into Peter’s raw palms. The gesture was so open, so un-selfconscious, that none of the other men paid it the slightest attention. It was simply one man tending to another, a practical act in a world governed by practicality.

By the time the bell rang to signal the end of the day, Peter felt a weariness so profound it was almost a spiritual state. His entire body was a single, throbbing ache. He trudged back to the bunkhouse in a stupor, his footsteps heavy and leaden. The simple acts of pulling off his new, heavy boots and washing his face in a basin of icy water required a monumental effort of will. But as he sat in the cookhouse that evening, a bowl of rich, thick soup warming his hands and the scent of woodsmoke in his hair, a new feeling began to surface beneath the exhaustion. It was a feeling of deep, bone-felt satisfaction. He had survived. He had faced the forest, the work, and the silent judgment of the men, and he had not broken. Later, lying in their bunk in the warm darkness, the aches in his body a dull, rhythmic thrum, Ewan’s arm came around him. "You did well today," Ewan murmured into his hair, his voice thick with sleep. "You didn't quit." Peter was too tired to form a reply. He simply leaned back into the solid warmth of Ewan's body, his mind empty, his body spent. He had endured his first day in the garden, and as he drifted into a heavy, healing sleep, he knew, with a certainty that settled deep in his marrow, that he had finally, truly, begun to put down roots.

The days that followed fell into a brutal, simple rhythm, governed by the clang of the bell and the slow, circling passage of the sun above the pines. Each morning, Peter woke in the warm haven of the bunk to a body that screamed a litany of new and inventive pains. The dull ache of the first day had sharpened into a fierce, articulate agony in his shoulders, his lower back, and most of all, his hands. The blisters had broken, leaving raw, weeping patches of skin on his palms that seared with pain at the slightest touch. Getting dressed was an ordeal of stiff, protesting limbs, and the walk to the cookhouse a slow, hobbling procession. The romance of their escape had been burned away by the harsh, unyielding reality of the work, leaving only the grim necessity of survival. He saw the doubt in the eyes of the other men, a silent wager on how long the city boy would last before he broke.

Out in the forest clearing, the axe was an instrument of torture. Every swing sent a shockwave of pain from his raw hands up his arms. His initial attempts to replicate Cal’s effortless grace were clumsy, pathetic failures. He was fighting a war on two fronts: one against the stubborn resilience of the pine branches, the other against the mutiny of his own body. He felt a rising tide of despair, a frustration so keen it brought hot tears to his eyes, which he angrily blinked away before anyone could see. He was a fraud, a boy who read about heroes, utterly useless when faced with the simple, honest challenge of a felled tree. He was just another piece of city grime that had washed up on their shore, and soon the tide of the work would drag him back out to sea.

The change came not as a sudden epiphany, but as a slow, painful surrender. Halfway through the third morning, his hands on fire, his back a knot of searing pain, he simply stopped. He leaned against the rough bark of the trunk, the axe hanging limply from his fingers, and closed his eyes, breathing in the cold, resinous air. He remembered Ewan's quiet words by the log pile: *Guide it, don't force it.* He had been trying to conquer the tree, to impose his will upon it through sheer, desperate effort. He opened his eyes, looked at the axe, and then at the smooth, flowing grain of the wood. He took a breath, adjusted his grip as Ewan had shown him, relaxing his fingers, and lifted the axe. This time, he didn't aim for a powerful, shattering blow. He aimed for a single point, letting the heavy head of the axe fall in a natural arc, his body moving with it, not against it. The blade hit with a clean, satisfying *thwack*, shearing a thick branch away with a sound like a breaking bone. There was no jarring shock, only a smooth transfer of energy, a feeling of rightness that was as surprising as it was profound. He did it again, and then again, slowly finding the rhythm, the secret cadence of the work.

From that moment on, the days began to transform. The work was still brutally hard, the exhaustion at the end of each day absolute, but the sharp edges of his despair began to wear away. He learned to read the language of the wood, to see the lines of force in a branch, to anticipate how it would split. The axe, once an enemy, became a familiar extension of his own arms, its weight a comfort, its worn handle a familiar landscape beneath his slowly toughening hands. His body, in turn, began its own slow transformation. The soft, pale skin of his palms thickened into a protective layer of callus. The undefined muscles of his arms and back hardened into taut, functional cords. He grew leaner, harder, the last of the city’s pallor scoured from his face by the wind and the sun. He was being remade by the forest, stripped down to his essential self and rebuilt with stronger materials. The other men, who had initially watched him with a mixture of pity and contempt, began to nod at him in the mornings, their greetings gruff but genuine. One afternoon, an older man named Findlay, a giant with a beard like a tangled bird's nest, paused by his tree. "You're holding the handle wrong for that angle, lad," he grunted, and spent two minutes demonstrating a different grip that saved Peter’s back from a world of unnecessary strain. The small, freely-given lesson was a quiet act of acceptance, an acknowledgment that he was no longer a guest, but part of the crew.

Their evenings in the bunkhouse became the anchor of his new life. The small, shared bunk in the corner was a world unto itself, a private island in the public sea of the sleeping quarters. After the exhaustion of the day, there was little energy for long conversations. Their intimacy was a thing of quiet, practical gestures. It was Ewan checking Peter’s hands each night, his rough fingers surprisingly gentle as he applied the pungent green salve to the new calluses. It was Peter saving a portion of his own tea for Ewan when he was late back from a task for Cal. It was the simple, unspoken comfort of lying in the dark, their tired bodies pressed together, a silent bulwark against the cold and the immense, wild darkness outside. Sometimes, when the ache in his muscles was too loud to allow for immediate sleep, Peter would lie awake and watch the slow, rhythmic rise and fall of Ewan’s chest, and a feeling of profound, quiet gratitude would wash over him. He had followed this man from a world of shadows and whispers into a world of hard truths and clean, sharp air, and in doing so, he had found not just a refuge, but a foundation.

One evening, a week into his new life, as Ewan was tending to a small cut on Peter’s forearm, a splinter from a rogue branch, Peter looked down at his own hands. They were almost unrecognizable. They were stained with pine tar, criss-crossed with small, healing scratches, the nails permanently grimed with earth. They were not the hands of a boy who turned the delicate pages of a book; they were the hands of a man who worked. He thought of the Peter in Glasgow, the lonely, fearful observer who lived vicariously through the stories of others, and he felt a vast, unbridgeable distance from that person. The fear that had been the constant background noise of his life had been replaced by the honest ache of labour, the anxiety of survival replaced by the simple, driving need to meet the bell in the morning. He flexed his fingers, feeling the pull of new muscle, the toughness of his own skin. He was still tired, still sore, but he was no longer fragile. The garden, he realized, was not just the forest around him. It was the new ground he was claiming inside himself, a place where he was learning not just to survive, but to grow.

The pain did not vanish. It simply changed its nature, transforming from the sharp, insistent cry of abused muscles into a dull, thrumming baseline, the familiar song of his own body’s strength. A month after their arrival, Peter moved through the forest with a competence that astonished him. The axe was no longer a foreign object but a part of him, its rhythm ingrained in his sinews. He worked alongside Findlay, the old giant, their two axes rising and falling in a steady, hypnotic cadence, a percussive duet that was their only necessary conversation. He learned to feel the weather in the ache of his joints, to gauge the time by the slant of the sun through the high canopy, to find a deep, almost spiritual satisfaction in the neat, orderly stacks of timber he left in his wake. The city boy was a ghost, a half-remembered story he might have read about someone else. The man who took his place was leaner, quieter, and as tough and resilient as the roots that snaked beneath his feet.

The routine was the bedrock of their lives, a predictable cycle of work, food, and sleep that left little room for uncertainty. But one evening, as the bell’s final clang echoed through the trees, Ewan broke the pattern. As the other men trudged wearily towards the promise of Annie’s stew, he caught Peter’s arm, his grip firm. "Not yet," he said, his voice low. "Walk with me." There was no command in his tone, only an invitation, a quiet offering of something outside the routine. Peter, his own weariness momentarily forgotten, simply nodded. The prospect of a few stolen minutes alone with Ewan, away from the communal warmth and noise of the cookhouse, was a luxury more tempting than any hot meal.

Ewan led him away from the main camp, following a narrow, winding deer-track that Peter had never taken before. The forest was a different creature in the gloaming. The shadows between the trees deepened from grey to a rich, velvety black, and the air grew still and cold, holding the scent of damp moss and decaying leaves. The boisterous sounds of the camp faded behind them, replaced by the deep, resonant silence of the woods, a silence punctuated by the snap of a twig underfoot or the distant, mournful hoot of an early-rising owl. They walked without speaking, their shoulders occasionally brushing, the shared silence as comfortable and familiar as the blankets on their bunk. After a ten-minute walk, the trees began to thin, and the roar of the sea, which was a constant, muted background hum at the camp, grew louder, more immediate. They emerged from the tree line onto a high, windswept headland of granite and tough, salt-strafed grass.

Below them, the North Sea was a vast, turbulent expanse of churning pewter, its white-crested waves crashing against the black, jagged rocks at the base of the cliffs with a force that seemed to shake the very ground they stood on. The sky was a masterpiece of bruised purple and faded rose, the last light of the sun bleeding away at the far horizon. The wind was a wild, untamed thing here, tearing at their clothes and whipping their hair across their faces. They found shelter in the lee of a monolithic granite boulder, a natural wall that shielded them from the worst of the gale. Ewan cupped his hands against the wind, his back to Peter, and with a few tries, managed to light one of their thinly-rolled cigarettes. He took a long drag, the red tip glowing brightly in the deepening twilight, and then passed it to Peter. The smoke, harsh and familiar, was a small, warm anchor in the immensity of the scene.

Peter took a slow, deep lungful, the smoke momentarily steadying him against the breathtaking scale of the view. He looked down at his hand holding the cigarette, at the hard-earned calluses, the ingrained dirt, the network of fine, silvery scars. "These don't feel like my hands anymore," he said, the words snatched from his lips by the wind. "I look at them, and I don't recognise the person they belong to. He knows how to use an axe. He isn't afraid of the cold. He isn't… afraid." He looked at Ewan, whose face was a mask of shadows, only his eyes catching the last of the light. "I spent my whole life in Glasgow being afraid. Of the noise, of the silence, of what people would think, of what I was. I didn't even realise how much space it took up inside me until it was gone."

Ewan was quiet for a long time, watching the endless, rhythmic assault of the waves on the shore below. He took the cigarette back from Peter, his fingers brushing against Peter's. "I was afraid, too," he confessed, his voice so low Peter had to lean in to hear it over the wind. "When we first got here. I watched you with that axe, and you looked like a sapling in a storm. I thought… I thought this place was going to break you." He turned to face Peter, his gaze intense, stripped of all pretence. "This forest, this coast… it’s the only place I ever felt I belonged. I brought you here, into the one part of the world that was truly mine, and I was terrified it wouldn't be big enough for you. That it would chew you up and spit you out, and I'd be alone in it again." It was the most vulnerable Peter had ever seen him, a confession that laid bare the deep fear of loss that underpinned his quiet strength.

This was a truth far deeper than any whispered endearment in the dark of their bunk. It was the bedrock on which their shared life was built. Peter reached out, not with the hesitant touch of the boy in the tenement, but with the steady confidence of the man he was becoming. He took Ewan’s hand, lacing his calloused fingers through Ewan’s own. It was a meeting of equals, a joining of two people who had been remade, both by their shared past and by this hard, beautiful place. It was a silent, binding promise. As they stood there, hands clasped, a new sound joined the roar of the sea—a faint, high-pitched, lonely cry from high above. Ewan tilted his head, his gaze sweeping the darkening sky. He pointed. "Look." A long, wavering V-formation of geese was etched against the last vestiges of colour in the sky, heading resolutely south. "They're leaving," Ewan said, his voice quiet, matter-of-fact. "Winter's coming." The sight was beautiful and profoundly desolate, a stark reminder that their small, hard-won sanctuary was about to be tested by a force far greater than any foreman or suspicious landlady.

They walked back to the camp in a deep, companionable silence, the shared knowledge of the coming challenge hanging between them not as a threat, but as the next chapter they would face together. The cookhouse was a beacon of light and warmth, the boisterous shouts and laughter of the men a welcome shield against the vast, cold darkness outside. Later, as they lay in their bunk, the sounds of the other men’s sleep a familiar chorus around them, Peter felt the press of the wind against the log walls, a low, mournful howl that promised colder nights to come. But curled against Ewan’s back, feeling the steady, slow rhythm of his breathing, he felt no fear. The city had been a cage that kept the world out. This place was a wilderness that invited the world in, demanding strength and resilience in return. They had survived the fall; now they would endure the winter. Together. The garden was being prepared for a long, deep sleep, and they would guard its roots until the spring.

The winter did not arrive with the gentle grace of a dusting on a postcard. It descended like a siege. For days, the sky had been a low, oppressive ceiling of bruised, colourless cloud, and the wind, which had been their constant companion on the cliffs, fell away into an unnerving, absolute stillness. The sea’s roar became a muffled, distant thunder, as if the world were holding its breath. The men in the camp grew quiet, their usual boisterous energy replaced by a watchful, introspective mood. They checked the seals on the windows, stacked firewood higher against the bunkhouse walls, and oiled their tools with a grim, focused industry. They were shoring up the ramparts against a known and respected enemy. Then, one afternoon as the light was already beginning to fail, it began. The first flakes were not small and delicate, but large and wet, like scraps of sodden linen falling from the grey sky. They melted as they hit the ground, turning the clearing into a dark, muddy slurry. But they did not stop. As the last of the twilight vanished, the temperature plummeted, and the wet flakes became a hard, dry, silent torrent of white.

Peter stood at the small, grimy window of the bunkhouse, watching the world disappear. The familiar shapes of the cookhouse and the workshop blurred, softened, and then were erased completely, swallowed by the swirling, hypnotic curtain of snow. The noise of the camp vanished, the world outside muffled into a profound, humming silence that was more absolute than anything he had ever experienced. The only sounds were the whisper of the snow against the glass and the low crackle of the stove inside, a sound that seemed impossibly fragile against the immense, silent power of the storm. The other men, finished with their evening meal, settled into the long night. Some played cards by the weak light of a lantern, their faces grimly focused. Others sat mending torn clothes or sharpening their axes, their movements economical and meditative. An air of quiet endurance filled the room. This was not a novelty; it was a known hardship to be weathered. Peter felt a hand on his shoulder and turned to see Ewan standing behind him, two steaming mugs of tea in his hands. Ewan didn't speak, just nodded towards the window, his expression a mixture of respect and grim resignation for the elemental force outside. They stood side-by-side, watching the blizzard rage, two silent sentinels guarding the small, warm pocket of life they had found against the vast, indifferent white of the world.

The morning bell was a muffled, distant clang, as if ringing from another country. When Cal heaved open the bunkhouse door, it was to a world remade, a landscape of impossible, sculptural beauty and stark, new dangers. The snow had stopped, leaving behind a deep, pristine blanket of white that had buried every familiar contour of the clearing. It lay in heavy, precarious drifts against the cabins and had transformed the felled logs and piles of branches into strange, organic mounds. The air was eye-wateringly cold and so still that the smoke from the cookhouse chimney rose in a perfectly straight, grey column against a sky of pale, washed-out blue. The beauty of it was breathtaking, an artist’s dream of pure form and light, but it was a hostile beauty. Every step was a struggle through thigh-deep powder. Every tool handle was a shock of vicious, biting cold. The trees in the forest were no longer just trees; they were laden with a crushing weight of snow, their branches bowed, creaking and groaning under the strain, each one a potential "widow-maker," ready to snap and fall without warning. The work had to continue, but the rules of engagement had changed completely.

For Peter, the first days after the snowfall were the hardest he had yet endured. The physical exertion of simply moving through the deep snow was exhausting, and the cold was a relentless, insidious enemy. It found its way through the layers of his woollen clothes, numbing his fingers and toes until they were clumsy, aching lumps. The sweat from his labour would freeze against his skin, creating a miserable, clammy chill that no amount of work could seem to burn away. He learned the hard way about the dangers of snow-blindness from the relentless glare off the white ground, and about the precariousness of his footing on hidden patches of ice. But he also learned the winter skills of the other men. He learned from Findlay how to wrap his boots in burlap for better grip, and from Cal he learned the art of looking up, of reading the stress on a branch and knowing which trees to give a wide berth. He learned to work in a new way, with a heightened awareness, his senses not dulled by the cold but sharpened by the constant, low-level threat of it. He was no longer just learning to work with wood; he was learning to work with winter.

The evenings became longer, darker, and more vital. The bunkhouse, once just a place to sleep, transformed into the heart of their small, isolated community. With the darkness falling by mid-afternoon, the men would gather around the pot-bellied stove, its heat a sacred circle in the freezing room. This was the time for stories. Men who were silent and stoic all day would open up in the warm, smoky gloom, their voices low as they spun tales of legendary storms, of close calls with death in the woods, of strange lights seen over the sea. Findlay, it turned in, had a fine, rumbling singing voice, and he would lead them in mournful ballads of lost love and shipwrecks, their voices a rough but moving chorus against the howl of the wind outside. In these moments, Peter felt the threads of community being woven tight around him. He was no longer the outsider, but a part of this collective, a keeper of the same fire. And later, in the absolute privacy of their shared bunk, burrowed deep under the heavy blankets, he would feel Ewan's cold feet seeking out the warmth of his own, and Ewan’s arms would wrap around him, a solid, living shield against the cold. In the profound, shared darkness, they would talk in whispers, their breath clouding in the tiny space between their faces, reaffirming their own small, tenacious existence against the overwhelming power of the season.

The first real test came a week after the snow, on a day so cold the trees themselves seemed to groan in protest. They were working a steep, difficult slope, felling a stand of old, thick-girthed pines. The snow was particularly deep, concealing treacherous hollows and loose rocks. Peter was working beside Findlay, their axes rising and falling, their breathing a harsh, rhythmic rasp in the still air. A team further up the slope, including Ewan and Cal, was preparing to bring down a true giant, a tree that had stood for a century. The warning shouts went up—"Timber!"—and Peter and Findlay paused, moving back to what they thought was a safe distance, their eyes on the magnificent tree as it began its slow, majestic, terrifying fall. But something was wrong. Its descent was not clean. Weighed down by an immense, unbalanced load of snow on one side, it began to twist, its great trunk groaning in protest. It wasn't falling where it was supposed to. It was coming their way, a monstrous, unstoppable force, its massive branches sweeping a deadly arc through the smaller trees, sending a shower of splintered wood and ice through the air. Findlay, who had been standing a few feet from Peter, gave a shout of pure, primal alarm. He had been caught on the wrong side of a deep snowdrift, his path of retreat blocked. He was directly in the path of the falling giant.

Time did not slow. It fractured. The world, which had been a steady rhythm of breath and axe-falls, shattered into a million sharp, chaotic fragments of sensory information. There was Findlay’s face, his mouth open in a silent, terrified ‘O’, his eyes wide with the stark knowledge of his own imminent death. There was the sound, a horrifying, drawn-out scream of wood fibres tearing apart, a sound that went straight to the bone. There was the sight of the giant pine, impossibly vast, seeming to hang in the air for a terrible, eternal second before it began its inexorable, twisting descent. And there was the snow, the deep, treacherous snowdrift that held Findlay in place as surely as if he were manacled to the ground. Peter’s mind was a blank, white void. The city boy, the boy who observed and feared and retreated, was gone, burned away in an instant of pure, animal instinct. His body moved, untethered from thought.

He launched himself forward, a desperate, lunging dive through the thigh-deep snow that felt like wading through thick, freezing treacle. Every step was a monumental effort, his lungs burning with the sudden, violent exertion. He heard shouts from the top of the slope, Ewan’s voice, a raw, terrified cry of his own name, but it was a sound from another world, distant and meaningless. The only reality was the few feet of snow between him and Findlay, and the monstrous, roaring shadow that was swallowing the sky above them. He reached the old giant, his hands grabbing a fistful of Findlay’s thick woollen jacket. There was no time for words, no time for anything but brute, desperate force. He planted his feet, digging for purchase he couldn’t find, and shoved with every ounce of strength his remade body possessed. It was like trying to move a mountain. Findlay, frozen in terror, stumbled, his weight a dead, uncooperative anchor. "Move!" Peter screamed, the word a raw, guttural bark he didn’t recognise as his own. He shoved again, a frantic, adrenaline-fuelled heave that sent them both staggering, falling sideways into the deep, soft powder of the snowdrift.

The world ended in a cataclysm of sound and fury. The roar of the falling tree was a physical force, a wave of displaced air that hit them like a solid object. The ground bucked and shuddered as the immense trunk impacted, a world-shattering *whump* that vibrated through Peter’s teeth and bones. A storm of snow, splintered wood, and frozen earth erupted around them, a blinding, choking chaos. A branch, thick as a man’s thigh, scythed through the air just inches above their heads with a sound like a tearing sheet, showering them with sharp splinters of bark and needles. Then, as suddenly as it had begun, there was a ringing, profound silence, broken only by the soft, settling sigh of displaced snow and the distant, panicked shouts of the other men. Peter lay half-buried in the snow, his face pressed into the cold, clean powder, his ears ringing, his mind a complete blank. He was alive. The thought was a small, flickering candle in the vast, dark emptiness of the shock.

He pushed himself up, his limbs trembling uncontrollably, a fine dusting of snow and pine needles clinging to his hair and clothes. The scene was one of utter devastation. The giant pine lay like a slain god, its massive trunk having carved a deep, raw wound in the earth, exactly where Findlay had been standing moments before. The air was thick with the powerful, funereal scent of crushed pine. A few feet away, Findlay was stirring, groaning, his face a mask of grey shock. He was trying to sit up, but one of his legs was trapped beneath a smaller, secondary branch that had snapped off in the fall, pinning him to the ground at an unnatural angle. Peter scrambled over to him, his hands patting him down, checking for injuries with a frantic urgency. "Findlay? Are you alright? Talk to me!" Findlay’s eyes, clouded with pain, focused on Peter. "My leg," he gasped, his voice thin and reedy. "God, Peter… my leg." Just then, the rest of the crew arrived, crashing through the undergrowth, their faces pale with terror. Ewan was at the forefront, his eyes wild, scanning the wreckage until they locked on Peter, alive and moving. The relief that washed over his face was so profound it was almost a mask of pain. He stumbled the last few feet and grabbed Peter’s arms, his grip bruising, his knuckles white. "I thought…" he started, his voice a choked, broken thing. "I saw you go for him. I thought you were both…" He couldn't finish, just pulled Peter into a fierce, desperate embrace that was less a hug and more an anchor, a frantic confirmation of life.

The moment was shattered by Cal’s voice, sharp and commanding, cutting through the chaos. "He's trapped. Ewan, get the big saw. The rest of you, clear this debris. Now!" The men, shaken but professional, instantly fell into their roles. The shock was replaced by a grim, focused purpose. They worked with a swift, coordinated efficiency that was a testament to their long experience with the forest’s dangers. Peter, released from Ewan’s grip, found himself working alongside them, his own shock suppressed by the urgent need for action. He helped clear the smaller branches, his hands, clumsy and trembling a moment before, now finding a steady rhythm. They worked to free Findlay’s leg, Cal directing the delicate operation with a calm authority, his face a grim, unreadable mask of responsibility. It took ten agonizing minutes to saw through the heavy branch and gently ease the old man free. His leg was a ruin, the bone clearly shattered below the knee, but he was alive. Cal fashioned a crude but effective splint from two straight branches and ripped strips of cloth from his own shirt, his movements quick and sure. The journey back to the camp was an arduous, silent procession. They made a makeshift stretcher from two poles and a stack of their own coats, and four of the strongest men, including Ewan, carried the injured man, their steps careful and slow through the deep snow. Peter walked alongside, carrying a handful of discarded axes, his mind still numb, the image of the falling tree replaying itself over and over behind his eyes. He had acted without thinking, a puppet pulled by some instinct he hadn’t known he possessed. He had stared into the face of death, and he had not flinched. He did not feel like a hero. He felt hollowed out, scoured clean, a stranger to himself.

That evening, the bunkhouse was a place of subdued, quiet reverence. Findlay lay on his bunk, his face pale but his eyes clear, his leg immobilised. Annie had come from the cookhouse, bringing with her not just food, but laudanum for the pain and a quiet, maternal authority that soothed the raw edges of the men’s nerves. A decision had been made: at first light, Cal and another man would take a sledge down to the nearest town to fetch the doctor. For now, all they could do was wait. The usual boisterous card games and storytelling were absent. The men sat quietly, smoking their pipes, the air thick with the unspoken acknowledgment of their shared mortality and their collective relief. As Peter sat on the edge of his own bunk, trying to coax feeling back into his numb hands, Cal came and stood before him. The big man looked down at him, his flinty eyes holding a new, unreadable light. "That was a damn fool thing to do," he said, his voice a low rumble. He paused, then added, "It was also the bravest damn thing I've ever seen." He clapped a heavy, calloused hand on Peter’s shoulder, a gesture that was both a commendation and a benediction. "You're one of us now, lad. For better or worse." He squeezed Peter's shoulder once, hard, and then walked away.

Later, in the profound, shared darkness of their bunk, curled under the heavy blankets, Ewan’s arm was not just a comfort, but a shield. He held Peter with a fierce, protective stillness, his body a solid line against Peter's back. For a long time, neither of them spoke. The events of the day lay between them, too large and raw for words. Finally, Ewan’s voice came, a rough whisper in the dark. "Don't you ever do that again." There was no anger in his voice, only the ragged, frayed edge of a terror he had been holding back all day. "Don't you ever scare me like that again, Peter." Peter didn't reply. He simply reached back and took Ewan’s hand, his newly calloused fingers lacing through Ewan's own. He held on tight, an anchor in the dark. He had faced the forest's fury and had not been found wanting. He had earned his place, not with the strength of his arms, but with the instinctive, unthinking loyalty of his heart. Winter had tested their small community, and they had held. He had been tested, and he had not broken. He was home.

The morning after the accident was born into a world of muffled silence and stark, crystalline light. The ringing of the bell seemed a violation of the profound quiet that had settled over the snow-bound clearing. In the bunkhouse, the men moved with a subdued gravity, the usual grumbled complaints and rough-housing absent. All eyes were on Cal and a wiry, taciturn man named Torquil as they made their preparations. They strapped snowshoes to their heavy boots and loaded a small, sturdy sledge with blankets, a flask of hot tea, and a bottle of whisky, provisions for a journey that was both a rescue mission and a gamble against the elements. The entire camp stood in the piercing cold to watch them depart, a silent, collective sending-off. There were no grand farewells, only a single, sharp nod from Cal before he and Torquil leaned into their harnesses and began the long, arduous trek towards the coast road, their dark figures shrinking against the vast, indifferent white until the forest swallowed them whole.

The work that day was different. The forest, which had begun to feel like a challenging but familiar partner, was once again an antagonist. The memory of the falling tree haunted the spaces between the pines, and every creak of a snow-laden branch was a fresh jolt of alarm. The men worked with a grim, sober focus, their movements more deliberate, their gazes constantly scanning the canopy above. The workload was heavier, the absence of three men—Findlay, Cal, and Torquil—a palpable gap in their ranks. Ewan, now the de facto leader, moved through the work teams with a quiet, anxious energy, his eyes everywhere at once. He assigned Peter to a task in a relatively clear, flat area, away from the treacherous slopes. It was the necessary work of splitting logs for the cookhouse stove, a job that was physically demanding but carried none of the immediate dangers of felling. Peter understood the unspoken motive behind the assignment. It was an act of protection, a manifestation of the terror that still lived behind Ewan’s eyes. A part of him, the new, capable part, bristled at being handled so carefully, but he said nothing, seeing the raw fear that Ewan was trying to master. He picked up the heavy splitting maul and set to work, the rhythmic, percussive thud of splitting wood a steadying counterpoint to the anxious thrumming in his own chest.

The subtle shift in his own status was undeniable. He was no longer the apprentice, the outsider to be tolerated. He was Peter, the man who had dived into the path of death to save one of their own. The change was not in grand pronouncements, but in the small, almost imperceptible gestures that formed the currency of respect among these quiet men. As he worked, a man named Angus, who had been one of the most openly dismissive of the "city boy" in the early days, walked over, silently took Peter’s axe, and spent a minute expertly honing its edge on a whetstone he produced from his pocket, before handing it back with a gruff, almost inaudible grunt. Later, during the mid-day break, as Peter sat alone on a log, nursing his still-sore hands, another man silently placed a second, thicker sandwich beside him. No words were exchanged, but the message was clear. He had paid a price, and in doing so, had earned his membership. He belonged not just to Ewan, but to the whole, ragged, hard-bitten family of the camp. It was a strange and unsettling feeling, this sense of belonging that had been forged in a moment of sheer, unthinking terror.

Ewan found him during that break, his face etched with the strain of command and a deeper, more personal worry. He sat beside Peter on the log, the silence stretching between them for a long minute before he spoke. "My first thought this morning," Ewan said, his gaze fixed on the distant, snow-shrouded hills, "was to tell you to stay in the cookhouse with Annie. To keep you out of the woods entirely." He let out a short, harsh breath. "I don't think I've ever been more afraid in my life than I was yesterday, watching you run towards that tree." He finally turned to look at Peter, his peat-smoke eyes dark with the memory. "But I couldn't. It wouldn't be right. You're not a guest here. You're a woodsman." Peter met his gaze, seeing the conflict raging within him—the fierce, protective instinct warring with his respect for the man Peter was becoming. "I'm not made of glass, Ewan," Peter said, his voice quiet but firm. Ewan’s mouth twisted into a wry, sad smile. "I know," he said, his voice rough with emotion. "I know you're not. That's what scares me."

Late in the afternoon, a shout went up from the man posted as a lookout. Two figures were emerging from the forest edge, pulling the sledge behind them. A third figure, small and dark-clad, walked beside them. The doctor. A wave of collective relief rippled through the clearing as the men abandoned their work and converged on the camp. Cal and Torquil looked utterly spent, their faces grey with exhaustion and rimmed with ice from their own breath. The doctor, a small, neat man with a clipped moustache and a face that seemed perpetually pinched against the cold, looked absurdly out of place, his black leather bag a strange, alien object in this world of wood and steel. He stamped the snow from his immaculate boots and disappeared into the bunkhouse where Findlay lay, his expression a mask of professional neutrality that offered neither hope nor despair. The men waited outside in the biting cold, a silent, anxious vigil, their rough camaraderie a solid, unspoken wall around their fallen comrade.

Peter and Ewan stood together, slightly apart from the main group, the steam from their own breath mingling in the frigid air. Peter felt the camp’s collective anxiety as a physical weight in his own chest. This was no longer just Findlay’s fate; it was a communal burden. The life they had here was hard, but it was honest and self-contained. The doctor, with his bag and his city knowledge, was a necessary intrusion, a reminder of a world beyond the pines where bodies were more easily mended but lives were, perhaps, more easily broken. After what felt like an eternity, the bunkhouse door opened, and Cal emerged, his face grim, followed by the doctor, who was wiping his hands on a small, clean handkerchief. The men pressed forward, a silent, questioning mob. The doctor addressed them all, his voice crisp and clear, cutting through the cold air. "It's a bad break. A spiral fracture of both the tibia and the fibula." The medical terms meant little to them, but the gravity of his tone was unmistakable. "I've set it as best I can and given him a strong dose of laudanum. But he can't stay here. As soon as a path is cleared, he needs to be taken to the infirmary in Aberdeen. He won't be climbing any hills for a very long time. If ever."

The finality of the verdict settled over the clearing like a fresh fall of snow, cold and heavy. Findlay, a man whose entire identity was tied to his physical strength and his mastery of the forest, had been severed from his purpose in a single, brutal moment. The thought was a chilling one, a reminder of the precariousness of their existence, of how quickly everything could be taken away. That night, the bunkhouse was hushed. Findlay was in a deep, drug-induced sleep, his leg a rigid, splinted shape beneath the blankets. The community had absorbed the blow and had a plan. They would care for him, they would get him to the city, they would see that he was provided for. The covenant held. In the deep, sheltering dark of their own bunk, Peter lay awake, listening to the wind howl around the corners of the cabin. The raw, physical ache of his own body was a comforting, grounding presence, a testament to his own wholeness. He thought of Findlay, of the life that had been so irrevocably altered. He turned, pressing his face into the warmth of Ewan’s shoulder. "What will happen to him?" he whispered into the darkness. Ewan’s arm tightened around him, a solid, reassuring weight. "We'll look after him," he murmured, his voice thick with sleep. "He's one of us." The words, the same ones Cal had spoken to Peter, were not just a statement, but a creed. It was the fundamental law of this place: you did not abandon your own. In the heart of the unforgiving winter, in a world stripped down to its barest essentials, Peter understood that he had stumbled into a family, bound not by blood, but by the shared, unspoken promise to catch one another when they fell.

The doctor left at dawn, a small, dark figure receding into the vast white landscape, a brief, sterile intrusion of the outside world that was now over. He left behind him a diagnosis and a death sentence for a way of life. The silence in the cookhouse that morning was as thick and heavy as the porridge in the bowls. The men ate without speaking, the scrape of spoons the only sound. Findlay, sedated and still in the bunkhouse, was a ghost at their table, his absence a gaping hole in their small fellowship. Cal, having returned with the doctor and snatched only a few hours of sleep, sat at the head of the table, his face a mask of grim authority. He drank his tea in slow, deliberate gulps, his flinty eyes scanning the faces of his crew, taking their measure in the wake of the crisis. The time for shock was over. Now was the time for logistics.

"We move him tomorrow, at first light," Cal announced into the silence, his voice flat and final, leaving no room for argument. "The snow has hardened. A sledge can make it to the coast road if we follow the riverbed. From there, we pray for a lorry." He outlined the plan with brutal simplicity. It would be a two-day journey, at best. A team of four to manage the sledge, which they would have to build that day. They would need to break trail through untouched snow, navigate treacherous ice on the frozen river, and camp one night in the open. It was a journey fraught with peril, undertaken for one of their own. "I'll lead," he continued, "and I'll take Torquil, he knows the river better than any man. I need two more. Strong backs, steady heads." The men at the table stirred, a low murmur of assent. Hands were ready to be raised. This was a duty, not a choice. Cal’s eyes moved down the table, assessing, calculating. He looked past men who had been with him for a decade, his gaze finally settling on Peter. "Angus," he said, nodding to the powerfully built woodsman who had sharpened Peter’s axe. Then, "And Peter."

A stunned silence fell over the table. Every eye turned to Peter. He felt the weight of their collective gaze, a mixture of surprise, doubt, and a new, grudging respect. He was the newest, the least experienced, the one who just yesterday was still considered an apprentice at best. To be chosen for such a crucial, dangerous task was an honour so profound it was terrifying. He saw Ewan, across the table, stiffen as if struck. "Cal, no," Ewan said, his voice a low, tight command. It was the first time Peter had ever heard him challenge his brother so directly in front of the others. "The lad’s not seasoned for this. It's two days in the open, in this cold. He'll break." The protective fury in Ewan’s voice was palpable, a raw, exposed nerve. But Cal’s expression did not soften. He met his brother’s gaze, his own eyes as hard and unyielding as granite. "He was seasoned enough yesterday," Cal said, his voice dropping, but carrying an edge that cut through the room. "He's light, which is good for the deep drifts. He's quick. And when the sky was falling, he didn't run. He ran towards it. I need a man who doesn't break. He goes."

The finality in his brother's voice left no room for appeal. Ewan stared at Cal for a long, tense moment, a silent battle of wills fought across the scarred wooden table, before he finally dropped his gaze, his jaw tight with a barely suppressed anger. The decision was made. Peter felt a strange, dizzying mixture of pride and pure, cold dread. He was being trusted with a life, with the honour of the camp. He had to be equal to it. The rest of the day was a blur of focused, purposeful activity. Under Cal’s direction, they constructed the sledge, a low, sturdy platform of seasoned pine fitted with smooth wooden runners. Peter worked alongside Angus and Torquil, his own clumsiness a stark contrast to their ingrained, effortless skill. But they did not mock him. They corrected him, their instructions gruff and minimal, accepting his presence as a fact decreed by their leader. He was part of the team. He watched them pack the supplies: dried meat, hard biscuits, ropes, extra blankets, a small medical kit prepared by Annie, and the precious bottle of whisky for emergencies. Every item was chosen with a stoic pragmatism that acknowledged the thin line between survival and disaster.

The departure was a quiet, solemn ritual in the blue, pre-dawn light. The whole camp turned out, their breath misting in the frigid air. Findlay, heavily sedated and wrapped in a cocoon of blankets and furs, was carefully lashed to the sledge. He was a still, silent passenger, his face pale and waxy in the dim light. Peter took his place at one of the four guide ropes, the rough hemp cold and stiff in his hands. He felt a touch on his arm and turned to see Ewan. He had come not to say goodbye, but to make a final inspection. He ran a critical eye over Peter’s gear, tugging the scarf tighter around his neck, checking the straps on his snowshoes. His movements were brusque, almost angry, but his hands lingered for a fraction of a second too long on Peter's shoulder. "Stay behind Cal," Ewan said, his voice a low, urgent murmur for Peter’s ears alone. "Watch his feet. Put your boots exactly where he puts his. Don't think, just follow." He pressed a small, flat metal flask into Peter’s hand, its contents sloshing softly. "For the cold," he said. It was an order, not a gift. He met Peter’s eyes, and in their peat-smoke depths, Peter saw a universe of unspoken fear. "Come back," Ewan whispered, the words so soft they were almost lost in the cold air.

Peter could only nod, his throat too tight for words. He gripped the flask, its cold metal a tangible link to the man he was leaving behind. Cal gave a single, sharp command, and the four men leaned into their ropes, taking the strain. The sledge runners groaned in protest against the snow, and then, slowly, ponderously, they began to move. Peter fell into step behind Cal, his eyes fixed on the back of the older man's boots, the rhythmic crunch of their snowshoes the only sound. He did not look back. He knew that if he did, he would see Ewan standing there, a solitary figure watching them go, growing smaller and smaller until the vast, silent, white forest reclaimed him. The garden, for the first time since he'd arrived, was now behind him, and ahead lay only the stark, unforgiving wilderness and a long road back to a world he had tried so hard to escape.
